dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A neat, well-appointed flat, tastefully decorated. Framed against a large window which looks out over the city, an elegant woman in her 70’s: EVELYN GREENSLADE. She’s on th phone, on hold. On the desk in front of her is a brand new laptop compute the screen reads ‘Getting Started ...’

dialogues.speaker: AUTOMATED VOICE
dialogues.text: (on phone) Thank you for your patience. Your call is important to us. We will be with you shortly. Evelyn's patience is strained nonetheless. She taps her fingers on the desk. AUTOMATED VOICE (cont'd) (on phone) Thank you for your patience. Your call is - A slightly-accented voice finally interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Mrs Greenslade, thank you for waiting -

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: (overlapping) Yes, now if you could stay on the phone for a moment and talk to me, just talk to me. I’m not even clear, I don’t actually understand what it is I’m trying to order. Is wireless the same as wi-fi? And what do either of them have to do with broadband?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Mrs Greenslade, since the account is not in your name, before we can make any changes we need to speak to the account holder. Can I please talk to the account holder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 2.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE
dialogues.text: I'm asking if I can speak to the account holder. Before we can make any changes -

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: You can’t talk to him, no. (beat) He's dead. He died. There’s only me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GILES, a judge in full wig and robes, moves quickly down corridor. He passes other judges, going the opposite way. He arrives at the office of GRAHAM DASHWOOD, goes in. GRAHAM is at his desk. His robes are on a hanger, his wig is on a stand beside him.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: We're late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later. Graham and Giles walk down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Bloody retirement parties. Hard cheese, soft wine, and endless speeches. Why do people do that? No one ever said about any kind of party: it was a wonderful occasion, just a shame that the speeches were so short.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: It’ll be you one day.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: One day very soon.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: You've been saying that for years. They walk into a large room, full of lawyers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At one end of the hall, a very old JUDGE is giving a very dull speech.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 3.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: An occasion such as this leads one to cast ones mind back to the days when I first entered my pupillage. I had the very good fortune of serving as a junior to Mr Justice Stancombe ... Graham's not listening any more. He’s looking around the room. At the old, tired faces. JUDGE (cont'd) ... the unwelcome news that I would transfer Chambers, bringing to mind the old adage a fronte praecipitium, a tergo lupi ... Everything seems to slow down, the judge’s mouth moving more and more sluggishly, though his voice remains the same. The effect is strange ... then the sound of laughte

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: This is the day. Everyone looks round at him. He’s almost as surprised as they are that he’s spoken out loud.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: Graham?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: This is the day. He turns and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staff bustle around a busy A & E ward. MURIEL lies on a bed in the corridor. The Head Nurse, KAREN, rushes past.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Listen, young lady. I want a cup of tea, and I want it now.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: The trolley will be along shortly.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: How hard d’you have to fall down before you get some proper attention? Hours I’ve been lying here, and not a single doctor has come to see me.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 3A.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Now that’s not quite true, is it Mrs Donnelly? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 4. KAREN (cont'd) A doctor did try and examine you, and you sent him away.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: That one? She looks up to the far end of the ward, where a doctor i washing his hands. He’s black.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: He can wash all he likes, that colour’s not coming out. I want an English doctor.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: An English doctor? Why didn’t you say so? I‘1l get one right away. She goes away, comes back moments later with a tall, handsome doctor. The bad news for Muriel is ... KAREN (cont'd) This is Dr Ghujarapartidar. And this is Mrs Donnelly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crescent of identical bungalows, part of a brand new retirement facility. A mobility scooter carrying an elderly resident trundles down the road.

dialogues.speaker: ESTATE AGENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ++. with an unlimited range of leisure opportunities just a stone’s throw away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young estate agent, EVAN, is showing DOUGLAS and JEAN around a very small, and very beige bungalow.

dialogues.speaker: EVAN
dialogues.text: So as I say, what you’re looking at here is very competitively priced, you can’t get better value for your grey pound. Another little feature, not necessary right now, but give it a couple of years ... (points) «+. rails on the walls to help you get around, and down here, a panic button in case of a sudden fall, brings the Warden running.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 4a.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: What if we fell somewhere else?

dialogues.speaker: EVAN
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: It’s just that we might not manage to plan our sudden fall in the exact corner where the button is.

dialogues.speaker: EVAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. As I say -  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 5.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: And would it be possible to get the rail to go through the middle of the room as well?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Darling ...

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: To help us get across, not just around?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: (to Evan) Could we have a moment, please? Thanks. Thanks so much. Evan goes.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Thirty years in the Civil Service and this is all we can afford?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Would it help if I apologized again?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: No. But try it anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUDITH (40ish) is sitting opposite someone. We don’t see whom.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: And then after that I worked as a systems analyst for a few years but I just found it so dull, what I really wanted was to do something that was more creative, that matched my ... (beat) I’m sorry. On the form they asked for our age bracket, and the age we wanted to meet ... and in both cases I ticked 35-45. Now we see the man she’s talking to. It’s NORMAN. He’s dapper, nice looking. And at least 70.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: That’s right, yes. So did I. They're at a speed dating evening. Numbered tables, etc. NORMAN (cont'd) Anyway, don’t stop. Something more creative ...  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 6.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Early 40's.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: D’you mean you were born in the early 40's?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Judy, I know what you’re asking -

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: It’s Judith.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Judith. And trust me, I've still got it. The bell goes; the signal for the women to get up and mov along to the next table. Judith leaves without looking back. NORMAN (cont'd) I just can’t find anyone that wants it. Another hopeful candidate arrives opposite Norman. And looks crestfallen at what’s on offer.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. BEDROOM/STAIRS/HALL. FAMILY HOUSE
dialogues.text: MADGE is in her bedroom. She’s arguing with her son-in-la CRAIG. Madge’s suitcases are by the door.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: This is crazy. You're crazy. You can’t just up and leave like this.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: And yet if you watch me, that’s exactly what you’1ll see happen. She picks up her suitcases, heads out of the room. Madge’ daughter JESSICA is on the landing.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Your mother’s lost it.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: My mother never had it.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 7.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Talk to her. She doesn’t listen to me.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Nobody listens to you. She heads down the stairs. Craig and Jessica follow. MADGE (cont‘d) (to Jessica) It’s one of the great mysteries of life that someone so vibrant and fascinating as my daughter should choose to spend her life with this fraction of a man.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: I still don’t understand what's going on.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: I just asked her to babysit. And now she says she’s leaving. They're at the bottom of the stairs. Jessica’s children, LIAM and KATIE, are watching.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: But you love babysitting.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: I loved it last night.

dialogues.speaker: LIAM
dialogues.text: We had pizza and stayed up late.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: And the night before.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: We had Chinese and stayed up late.

dialogues.speaker: LIAM
dialogues.text: If you don’t go, tonight we could do a curry.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: It’s tempting, my darlings, but you know why I must leave.

dialogues.speaker: LIAM
dialogues.text: We know.

dialogues.speaker: KATIE
dialogues.text: (to her parents) Being here is stopping her finding a husband.  10 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 8.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Another one?

dialogues.speaker: LIAM AND KATIE
dialogues.text: Bye Granny.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Don’t let the buggers get you down. Madge turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: How many husbands have you had, anyway? She turns back, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Including my own? Then she’s out of the front door, and heading for the tax

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: Mother? Mother!

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. TAXI
dialogues.text: Moments later. Madge climbs into the back of the cab.

dialogues.speaker: TAXI DRIVER
dialogues.text: Name the place, darling. Where are you going? Madge smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: I have absolutely no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn, whom we saw earlier on the phone, is in the livin room. Her son CHRISTOPHER is there. And her lawyer HAROLD.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: There’s no other way . There just isn’t. Harold told us this three months ago.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: And I’m afraid matters have only got worse.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 8A.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: We can’t wait any longer. We need to put this flat on the market, and at least make a start at paying off Dad’s debts. te ee  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 9. Christopher turns to Harold. They wait CHRISTOPHER (cont'd) I’ve talked it through with Polly and the boys, and of course we all agreed. Ma will move in with us.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I think that’s best, Evelyn. It’s what Hugh would’ve wanted. for confirmation from Evelyn. None comes.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Good. Settled. End of discussion.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: That’s what your father used to say.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Ma -

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: When there’d never really been any discussion at all.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: I want to look after things for you.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Like he did for forty years

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: And look how that turned out. She turns to Harold EVELYN (CONT’D) How can any of us know what Hugh would've wanted? And would he have seen fit to tell us anyway? (Best) Obviously the flat has to be sold. (Best, then to Christopher) And you're very kind. And dear Polly. But no, I won’t be coming to live with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 9A. il INT. HOSPITAL - DAY 11 Muriel has now been transferred to a ward. She is listening to DR GHUJARAPARTIDAR.

dialogues.speaker: DR GHUJARAPARTIDAR
dialogues.text: You need a new hip, Mrs Donnelly. It’s not a difficult operation.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Easy for you to say, you're not having it.

dialogues.speaker: DR GHUJARAPARTIDAR
dialogues.text: Regardless. You do need a new hip.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: I’m not getting it from you.  12 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 10.

dialogues.speaker: DR GHUJARAPARTIDAR
dialogues.text: Not me personally, no.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Not any of your lot.

dialogues.speaker: DR GHUJARAPARTIDAR
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: So when do I have the operation?

dialogues.speaker: DR GHUJARAPARTIDAR
dialogues.text: I’m afraid you'll be on a waiting list for at least six months.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: At my age, I can’t plan that far ahead. I don’t even buy green bananas.

dialogues.speaker: DR GHUJARAPARTIDAR
dialogues.text: There is another way. Our hospital trust is funding a new pilot scheme, that will enable us to out-source you to another hospital, where they can perform the procedure almost immediately, and at a fraction of the cost.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Is it local?

dialogues.speaker: DR GHUJARAPARTIDAR
dialogues.text: That depends how you define local. INT. EVELYN'S FLAT/CHRISTOPHER’S OFFICE - NIGHT 12 Evelyn is on the phone to her son Christopher. They’re both sitting at computers. Evelyn’s new-found dexterity i impressive. Around Evelyn’s room are packing boxes, some already full

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: (on phone) When did you get a computer?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: How far along is the progress bar? The strip at the bottom that tells you -

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: I know what it is. What are you showing me anyway?  13 14 15 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 11. The webpage has come up. It’s a picture of a beautiful ol building. And underneath is written ‘THE BEST EXOTIC MARIGOLD HOTEL’. As Christopher gapes in horror, he hears a mellifluous Indian voice.

dialogues.speaker: INDIAN VOICE
dialogues.text: ‘Come and spend your autumn years in an Indian palace with the sophistication of an English country manor. Steeped in the tradition of the Raj, tucked away on the outskirts of Jaipur ...’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mellifluous tones continue. Madge mouths the words to herself as she scans the same web-page.

dialogues.speaker: INDIAN VOICE
dialogues.text: ‘... it exudes historical ambience and is graced with breathtaking surroundings ...’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean, whom we earlier saw looking at the bungalow, is at the hairdressers. Her stylist ABI listens to her reading computer printout for the same hotel. Which looks classy, elegant, and welcoming. Madge’s voice bleeds into Jean’s.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (reading) ‘Lofty terraces, open courtyards, domes, arches and canopied balconies transport one back in time.’

dialogues.speaker: ABI
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t mind going there myself.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: In the background, a train rumbles along the Piccadilly Line towards Heathrow. Douglas, Jean’s husband, is on the green with his friend SIMON. Douglas is lining up a tricky putt.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: There won’t be any golf courses.  16 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 12.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Just as well. I can’t afford the green fees.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: But a retirement home? Douglas misses his putt.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: It’s a luxury development, where all the residents are in their golden years.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Like the Costa Brava.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Yes. But with more elephants. Simon holes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham, the judge, is in his office. It’s nearly empty; his entire life is being packed away. His friend Giles watches him put more things in boxes.

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: How long have we known each other? And you’ve never once talked about India.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: D’you want these books?

dialogues.speaker: GILES
dialogues.text: You might need them again. Graham smiles at him, calls out.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Mrs Megson! His cleaner, MRS MEGSON, comes in.

dialogues.speaker: MRS MEGSON
dialogues.text: Sir? Graham takes a beautiful vase off the shelf, gives it to her. I want you to have this.

dialogues.speaker: MRS MEGSON
dialogues.text: Are you sure?  17 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 13.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Absolutely. There’s a slight crack on the bottom. But I think you might know something about that already. Mrs Megson goes. GRAHAM (cont‘’d) I used to live there. A long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bedsit. Slightly down at heel, and sparsely furnished. Norman, whom we met speed dating, is talking to someone. We don’t see who. Quietly, in the background, Radio 2 music from an old battery radio.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I have to go. I do. And I could say I wish you'd come, but I've never lied to you. We both know I need more than you can offer. We know that. Don’t we? We see who's sitting in front of him. An ancient dachshund. NORMAN (cont’d) (to the dog) Don’t make that face at me. Norman's Polish landlady, MRS JELLINEK, is at the door.

dialogues.speaker: MRS JELLINEK
dialogues.text: (to her dog) You. Upstairs. The dog hops off the chair, and leaves. Norman watches hi go. MRS JELLINEK (cont'd) Any warm clothes you have use for no more, I take them. And not forget to leave keys when you go. She leaves. Norman is left alone.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I'll miss you too.  18 19 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The district ambulance driver, JACKSON, is pushing Muriel in a wheelchair across a housing estate.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: You know who'll be there, don’t you? Indians. Loads of them, A sea of brown faces and black hearts, all greasy haired and reeking of spices. Never see one on their own, do you? No, becuase they hunt in packs. All the better to rob me blind and -

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: You know what? You can take it from here.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: You’re supposed to see me into my flat. That's what they said.

dialogues.speaker: JACKSON
dialogues.text: My wife is from Mumbai. He heads off. Muriel shouts after him.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: No good moaning to me, mate. You married her! But he’s gone. Muriel wheels herself on over the bumpy ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A reluctant Christopher is pushing a trolley carrying Evelyn’s cases to the terminal.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: You’re sure your tickets are in order?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: They should be. The hotel paid for them. I’m sure they'd rather have us there than not. And its fantastically cheap for the first three months.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: I wonder why. They walk on in silence. CHRISTOPHER (cont‘d) How will we know you’re alright?  20 21 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I’ll call. They do have phones there, you know. Or you can just read my blog.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Your what?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: On the interweb. You can log in whenever you like, read my news.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: I just hope the first item will be announcing your return. Ir don’t suppose they’1ll be paying for the journey back...? Evelyn stops. They’ve reached the terminal.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Could you please, before I go, say one thing that is supportive? Because I’ve never done anything like this before.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Without Dad, you never did anything at all. And i don’t think you’1l be able to cope.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Well. I suppose we'll find out, won't we? They head into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madge is at the First Class Check-In desk.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: And the connecting flight to Jaipur is first class too? 15. 20 The check-in girl nods, hands Madge back her passport. MADGE (cont'd) I tell you, it’s tough to get upgraded nowadays. I had to flirt so hard with the travel agent, it was practically phone sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light is fading. 21  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 15A. Norman appears to be relishing a detailed search from a female Security Guard.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Come on. Thorough as you like Muriel is waiting to collect her bag from the belt.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: We'd like to take a look in this bag, Madam, if you don’t mind. He lifts the bag onto a table. It’s heavier than he thought.  22 23 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 16. SECURITY GUARD (cont’d) What you got in here anyway? He opens the bag, stares in astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: PG Tips. Brown sauce. Ten jars of Marmite. Thirty one packets of Chocolate Hobnobs. Pickled onions. Pickled eggs. And pickle.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: No liquids on the plane.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: It means you can’t take the pickled onions. Or the pickled eggs. (beat) The pickle’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The passengers from Flight 1045 to Delhi are seated at th gate, waiting to board. Muriel is wheeled up by an attendant and parked at the en of the only remaining row of empty chairs. Douglas and Jean are already sitting there. Jean smiles politely as Graham sits down a couple of seat away. Norman arrives, carrying his battery radio, sees an empty place between Jean and Madge, who is sitting at the end. He smiles knowingly at Madge as he sits. Finally Evelyn takes the only available space, between Graham and Douglas. And there the seven passengers wait patiently, unaware of their common fate. The sound of a jet engine, quiet at first, finally engulf them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane cruises down through a stunning sunset, and lan at Delhi Airport.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn, Douglas, Jean and Graham are descending on an escalator. Madge is a few steps up.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Obviously one’s read one’s Kipling, but we view this as an opportunity to explore another culture, as well as making new friends. And a retired judge is just the class of guest one was hoping for, isn’t it Douglas?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (to Evelyn) And is this your first time in India?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You don’t seem like an experienced traveller.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I'm not. Although one has read one’s guidebooks. Jean blinks. Evelyn and Graham share a smile. Douglas hides his. And Madge sees it all. As they head towards the baggage carousel, they’re met by Muriel and Norman, emerging from the elevator. Norman is pushing Muriel’s wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Norman Cousins.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Madge Hardcastle. A pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Play your cards right, it could be. Madge stares at him. A voice comes over the tannoy.

dialogues.speaker: AIRPORT ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, we regret to inform you that owing to bad weather, Flight 105 to Jaipur has been cancelled. The airline is happy to arrange ...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 25 26 27 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hours later. The airport is deserted, except for the Marigold Hotel party, who sit slumped and exhausted on another row of seats, with Muriel’s wheelchair at the oth end. After a moment, Graham says ...

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Alright. Plan B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later. They’re all moving briskly through the hi- tech, ultra-modern, beautifully air-conditioned building.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Of course it’s a good idea. Who can you trust if not a High Court Judge?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: And this way we see more of the country. Norman is pushing Muriel’s wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (leaning down, to Muriel) If anyone asks, say you’re my mother. I don’t want people to think we're together.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: In your dirty dreams.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Douglas, these are not words that often pass my lips, but you may actually be right. The country seems to be rather more civilised than one originally thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later. Our heroes are in the middle of an extraordinary scene. Stifling heat, deafening noise; the chaos, the bustle, the grime, the crowds, the life. They’re surrounded by taxi drivers, baggage handlers,beggars etc. All clamouring for their attention. Evelyn looks a little shocked. Jean is traumatized, a handkerchief to her face.  28 29 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 19. Graham, at the ticket booth, triumphantly holds up a fistful of tickets.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (shouting over the din) The bus will drop us in the centre of town. We can take tuk- tuks the rest of the way! They follow him through the hordes. And see their bus. It’s absolutely rammed. People are practically hanging ou of the windows.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: There’s not enough room.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: It’s time to prove the first and only rule of India: there's always room. He starts to fight his way to the door. Evelyn’s at the back. She stops, for a moment, looks around her.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: What larks, Pip. Douglas is just ahead of her. He turns, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Let's hope so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel’s wheelchair is strapped to the back of the bus, which is screaming down the six-lane highway. A huge towe of luggage is piled precariously on the roof. The road appears to be complete chaos; cars, buses, even cows overtaking each other. The bus pulls into the outside lane to follow a truck whi is overtaking some slower vehicles. As the truck pulls ba into the inside lane, it reveals a huge truck barrelling towards them on the wrong carriageway. Norman, sitting at the front, screams his last scream...

dialogues.speaker: NOOOOOOO.....1
dialogues.text: At the last minute, the bus pulls back into the inside lane. The Indians on the bus take absolutely no notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman is grinning from ear to ear.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 20.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I‘m loving this! Evelyn is sitting next to Madge.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: A few months ago I was organising the church flowers.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Are you struggling with the feeling you're not in control of your circumstances?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: A little.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: You know what the shortest prayer in the world is?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Fuck it. Evelyn laughs. MADGE (cont’d) You're not doing the church flowers any more. May as well enjoy the ride. Douglas is watching a nice Indian family. They’re having picnic. The father notices Douglas looking, offers him some food. Douglas makes the namaste gesture, takes some happily.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Are you insane? “Avoid all food not from a reputable vendor, it will have been washed with impure water.” Douglas keeps eating, with great enjoyment.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS,
dialogues.text: It’s just a sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Marvellous. Then I’11 have the ham, cheese, and streptococcus, please. Or perhaps the bacteria, lettuce and tomato. Douglas turns to Muriel.  30 31 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 21.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Would you like some of this? I believe it’s aloo ka paratha.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: If I can’t pronounce it, I’m not eating it. The cacophony of horns continues. Jean screams, as anothe collision looms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last of the light. The bus moves on through a beautif landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is asleep, or trying to sleep. Except Muriel. She reaches into her bag, and carefully removes a biscuit. She surreptitiously lifts it to her mouth, and starts to chew. Madge has fallen asleep on Evelyn’s shoulder. But Evelyn is still awake, as is Graham.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: How long since you were here?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Forty years.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: As long as I was married. (beat) He died recently. My husband.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: D‘you think we’re going to be alright?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: God, don’t ask me. I’m more scared than you are. They both smile, sit in silence for a bit. GRAHAM (cont’d) Yes. I think it’s going to be extraordinary.  32 33 34

dialogues.speaker: 34B
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun rises. A beautiful, pearly dawn. The bus drives through the great gates of Jaipur. Below, the city shimmers in the heat. It’s a magnificent sight.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What exactly is a tuk-tuk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our heroes are squashed into a pair of them, facing forwards and backwards, attempting not to swallow too muc dust as they wheel crazily through the teeming morning streets of the city. They stare in amazement at the world racing past them. A scooter overtakes. A young man is driving, his girlfriend riding side-saddle on the back. Her sari billows out behind her. Douglas and Evelyn both watch her struck by this image of beauty, youth and vitality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tuk-tuks have pulled up, and our travellers emerge, exhausted and dirty, staring through some garden gates at the Marigold Hotel. Once a beautiful building, once possibly even luxurious, it is clearly in the process of being given at least half the face-lift it badly needs. Parts of the building are freshly painted, some of the ornate balconies are crumbling, and one wall is clad with crazily skewed bamboo scaffolding. A huge old tree towers over an untended garden, its branches poking into the windows of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young man leans out from an upper balcony to see the arrival below: SONNY KAPOOR (early 20's). He deposits a paint pot and brush on a parapet, and races off across the rooftop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dazed and horrified, the travellers wander up the pathway A cow standing in front of them is pushed into the garden by a couple of young houseboys who then run to the tuk-tu to collect their luggage.  34c 35 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny clatters down the steep steps, and comes tearing ou onto a verandah, as the travellers arrive in the courtyar below. He spreads his arms wide.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Welcome to India!!! They stare up at him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. COURTYARD/HALLWAY.BEDROOM. MARIGOLD HOTEL
dialogues.text: The courtyard is not without charm, although somewhat delapidated. A fountain at the centre does not look as if it has seen water in years, and faded awnings are strung haphazardly. Sonny is leading Madge into the darkness of the building, towards her room.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: This is a building of the utmost character, which means that perhaps not everything will function in the way you expect it to. But as the manager and chief executive supervising officer of the Marigold Hotel, I can tell you with great pride that the building has stood for centuries, and will stand for many more, in 100% shipshape condition. Please follow me, carefully avoiding that naughty stone there ... round this corner, leading us most successfully all the way to ++. your bedroom! The room is very small, comfortable, and tastefully decorated. But there‘s no door.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Here. In here.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: My dear man. Rooms have doors. What you’re showing me here is an alcove.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: The door is coming soon, most definitely.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: How soon?  36 37 38 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 24.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Let us not concern ourselves with details, Mrs Hardcastle. Rather than speaking of doors, we should instead take pleasure in the freedom to roam.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Does your room have a door?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Oh yes.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Then that’s where I’1l be staying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas and Jean arrive at their room. Douglas goes in through the arched doorway, promptly comes back out again

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Bird in the room! Bird in the room! Jean pushes him aside, goes on in. Several pigeons are flying around in some panic.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. VERANDAH/BEDROOM. MARIGOLD HOTEL
dialogues.text: Evelyn arrives at her room, goes on in. The room is light and airy. And rather nice. But all the furniture is covered in sheets. As Evelyn stands there, Sonny comes rushing in, yanks all the sheets off, and runs out again.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. BEDROOMS/TERRACE. MARIGOLD HOTEL
dialogues.text: Muriel wheels herself towards her room. Standing inside i a male nurse, AJIT. Muriel swivels her chair around. Graham is just going int his room.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: There's an Indian in there! Graham smiles, goes on into his room. Which is dusty, but comfortable and pleasant. He looks around with satisfaction.  39 40 41 42 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman is laboriously climbing the stairs to his room. He stops, catches his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ajit is attempting to explain himself to Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: My what?

dialogues.speaker: AJIT
dialogues.text: Your physiotherapist. To help with your recovery after the operation.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: You're not touching me.

dialogues.speaker: AJIT
dialogues.text: Traditionally that is how physiotherapy is practised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman comes out onto the roof of the hotel. His room is right in front of him, a kind of penthouse cabin. A bed, but not much else. The trees poke in through the open window. He walks through the room, hangs his battery radio on a hook and leans out of the balcony, surveying the view.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: This‘1l do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean is confronting Sonny.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I want to stay at the other hotel, the one in the brochure.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Mrs Ainslie, prepare to be amazed. This is that very building!

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You've Photoshopped it!

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I have offered a vision of the future. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 43 44 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 26. SONNY (cont'd) Of course I had hoped that by now it would be the present. But in India we have a saying: everything will be alright in the end. So if it is not alright, then it is not yet the end.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: What will start to make this alright is for you to give us a refund.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Of course if that is what you desire, you must have it. Absolutely no problem, I will refund you completely.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You will? Straight away?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Without question, Mrs Ainslie, I most definitely will. Straight away in three months. INT. GRAHAM‘’S ROOM. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 43 Graham is taking some things out of his bag: an old map o Jaipur, sepia-tinted photographs of a British family duri the Raj, official documents yellowing with age. He picks up a photograph, looks at it. From outside, we can hear Ajit, the physiotherapist ...

dialogues.speaker: AJIT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: «+. a stay of five days and it is done under general anaesthesia. A hip replacement usually takes only two hours ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ajit’s explanation continues. Muriel is trying not to panic.

dialogues.speaker: AJIT
dialogues.text: Your surgeon will remove the top end of the thigh bone, and insert an artificial bone instead. A most routine procedure.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Have you got a marker pen on you?

dialogues.speaker: AJIT
dialogues.text: Why?  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 27.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: I want to mark it. So you don’t take the wrong hip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas is on his way down the stairs. Evelyn comes out of her bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Oh, hello.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Is everything alright?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I was just going to find the manager. DOUGLAS. I'm afraid he’s dealing with my wife. Or vice versa.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I promised I‘d call my son, to tell him I’d arrived, and -

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: And the phone in your room doesn’t work. May I? 45A INT. EVELYN’S ROOM. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 45A Douglas picks up the very old-style phone. Evelyn is watching. DOUGLAS (cont’d) Now, did you try jiggling it a bit?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Yes, did that.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Did you kind of bang it lightly on the desk a few times?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: That too.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Emm. He twists off the mouthpiece of the receiver, lifts the receiver carefully. And blows on it.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 28.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: How did you come to be here? In India.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: I invested our - well, my - retirement money in our daughter's internet company. She assured me that as soon as the start-up actually started up, and the conversion from virtual to actual proved sufficiently viable, then she would be able to pay it all back.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I understand what most of those words mean.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: It turns out neither did she. Douglas has put the mouthpiece back on, holds the receive to his ear. DOUGLAS (cont’d) There you are. Good as new.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: No, of course not. I’ve got no idea what I’m doing. Evelyn bursts out laughing. DOUGLAS (cont’d) Now, would you like me to not fix that chair? Because I can do that too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The houseboys are struggling with the unequal task of pulling Muriel’s wheelchair, with Muriel in it, up the narrow steps.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: In honour of your arrival, a special welcome British roast for you all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of mismatched table and chairs, that constitute t dining area of the hotel.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 29. Sonny is serving up a meal. His guests, wearing garlands of marigolds, listen politely.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: -..Cooked lovingly by myself and my most loyalist factotum and helper, Young Wasim ... He points to YOUNG WASIM. Who is about 80, and is sitting in the corner, fast asleep.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Roast what?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: A wonderful taste of Blighty.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Roast what?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Roast goat curry. DOUGLAS. Yes please.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: So the upshot is that he’s spent all our money getting us here, and we can‘t leave till he’s made some more. Muriel has arrived at her table.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Gentle friends, you have found your way to this place, bequeathed to me by my beloved father, that I have raised from the ruins of his broken dreams, and renamed The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel For The Elderly And Beautiful. Yes, I use the words most deliberately.... Norman is not looking very well at all. Sonny doesn’t notice, keeps on going. SONNY (cont'd) ++-You have all heard the chimes at midnight, and long in tooth have you become. Who knows how many days you have left? But we are most honoured that you have chosen to spend that time with us. Norman’s head suddenly tips forward, and he falls from hi chair onto the floor.  47 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 30. General panic. Everybody crowds round, but no one knows what to do. SONNY (cont'd) Let me through, please. My brother is a doctor. He kneels next to Norman, and checks his watch as he feel for a pulse. Everybody waits. And then ... SONNY (cont’d) This man is dead. An appalled silence. SONNY (cont'd) Please, we must cover his face. We should preserve his dignity at this terrible moment. Madge looks around. All there is is a napkin. She passes it Sonny, who lays it over the face of Norman. Who promptly coughs.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: He just coughed. I heard him cough!

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: He moved! He’s alive!

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: He’s fainted, that’s all. Sonny shakes his watch next to his ear. It’s stopped. Norman sits up.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: What’s going on? Did I nod off? Everyone crowds round Norman, helps lift him back up. Except Muriel. She just stares at them all.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Hell. I’m in hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun rises. A washer-man bicycles up to the hotel, a load of clean sheets balanced on his handlebars. Shopkeepers on the street are beginning to set out their wares.  48 49 50 51 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 31.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Day Nine. Old habits die easier than we think, and new ones form. INT. EVELYN’S ROOM, MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAWN 48 Evelyn is typing - hunt and peck - at her computer. Besid her, the classified pages of the local newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: No longer do I reach out in the morning for Radio 4. My news comes instead from the Jaipur Herald ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sign reads: ‘THE BEST EXOTIC MARIGOLD HOTEL FOR THE ELDERLY AND BEAUTIFUL - OPEN FOR BUSINESS.’ Sonny affixes a sticker: ‘NOW WITH GUESTS!’

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: +++ Soon I might even grow accustomed to the storm of car horns and vendors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The main road in Jaipur is chaotically busy. Crowds, bikes, cows, dust, noise, and laughter. Sonny's battered old car has broken down. Madge is in the front seat, Douglas and Jean in the back. Sonny is aiming a couple of kicks at the engine.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Can there be anywhere else in the world that is such an assault on the senses?

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. PUBLIC RECORDS OFFICE, JAIPUR
dialogues.text: An office out of a Kafka novel; cloth bags containing fil are piled all around the room, floor to ceiling. Graham is seated at a desk, in front of a sober official. He is filling in a form.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Those who know the country of old just go about their business. But nothing can prepare the uninitiated for this riot of noise and colour ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52 53 54 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman seems less interested in the astonishing geometric devices of the ancient observatory than in the female tourists who have come to see them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chaos and din of the street is even more mind-bogglin Madge now has the bonnet up, and is studying the engine. Douglas stands in the street, staring in wonderment aroun Inside the car, Jean looks utterly traumatized, shrinking lower in her seat as a horde of kids swarm at the windows shouting, wheedling, gesticulating. Sonny does his best t wave them away.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: ++. for the heat, the motion, the perpetual teeming crowds. Sonny is conducting his own personal assault on our senses ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guests look on with trepidation, as another meal is laid before them.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: +». with the flow of exotic dishes he demands daily from the kitchen. Mooli Moong Dal. Baghara Baingan. Banjari Gosht. Paneer Methi Chaman ... As the list unfolds, the guests, one by one, enter their bathrooms; a litany of doors closing ... Until Norman. EVELYN (V.0.) (cont‘d) Mutton Vindaloo ... Norman lies on his bed, reading the Kama Sutra. He spins the book round, in order to study an illustratio more intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hospital puts the NHS to shame. It’s hi-tech, bright, and spanking clean.  55 56 57 58 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 33. Sonny pushes Muriel through the doors of the lobby. The reception area is a forest of dark skin. Muriel is rigid with fear.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Initially you’re overwhelmed. But gradually you realise: it’s like a wave. Resist, and you'll be knocked over ... Sonny is in discussion with some doctors. Then he turns to see that Muriel has vanished. Through th window Muriel can be seen frantically wheeling herself aw down the path... EVELYN (V.0O.) (cont’d) Dive into it, and you'll swim out the other side.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. STREET/ROOM, MARIGOLD HOTEL
dialogues.text: Madge is exchanging some coins with a street trader in return for a mobile phone. In her room, Madge scans a phone directory, and dials a number.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: This ig a new and different world. INT. EVELYN’S ROOM, MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 56 Evelyn is finishing her blog. She picks up the paper, checks something.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: The challenge is to cope with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn is coming down the path to the gate.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And not just cope ... but thrive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn is walking down a rough street on the outskirts of the city. Kids are everywhere, laughing, shouting, doing tricks, begging. Evelyn approaches them, holding up a piece of paper.  59 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 34.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Please, can anyone direct me to this address? Evelyn’s piece of paper gets passed around: none of the kids can read. An older boy finally points. Suddenly there's lots of pointing. EVELYN (cont'd) Thank you. She goes to move, but the kids are still all around her. EVELYN (cont'd) I’m sorry, I don’t ... I don’t really have much ... She gives them the contents of her pockets. EVELYN (cont’d) Alright? Alright now? Goodbye. She starts to walk, is surprised that the entire posse of kids walks with her. In fact, the group seems to be growing exponentially. She looks like the Pied Piper. INT. DOUGLAS AND JEAN‘’S ROOM, MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 59 Douglas is getting ready to go out. Jean clearly isn't.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Graham was talking about this marvellous temple. I thought you might want to come with me.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I’m your wife. Have we met?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: You'd really rather stay here all day?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Given the alternative, yes.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS,
dialogues.text: When I walk out in the morning, the street kids all smile at me.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Because you give them money.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: One does this trick where he holds his hands out in front of himself, and then swings through his own arms. Got to be worth a rupee or two. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 34A. DOUGLAS (cont'd) (Beat) I’11 go on my own then.  60 61

dialogues.speaker: 61A
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road is absolutely rammed; with cars, bikes and rickshaws. All honking horns, all seemingly headed in different directions. Evelyn has somehow made it to the central reservation. Sh takes a deep breath, and plunges into the maze of traffic heading for the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham is in a rickshaw. The rickshaw driver, PRAVESH, is driving it through a neighborhood in transition. Skeletal structures of a new India rise above the houses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some kids playing cricket. The rickshaw weaves its way through them and comes to a halt. Graham gets out, and stands in the street, dwarfed by a huge modern building, some months away from completion.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: This can’t be right, surely?

dialogues.speaker: PRAVESH
dialogues.text: I am thinking so, saab.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: But there were houses all along here ... these were homes.

dialogues.speaker: PRAVESH
dialogues.text: I can take you some other place..?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: No. That’ll do for now. Thank you. He hands over some money, and Pravesh pedals away. Graham turns to look at the boys playing cricket. One of them, SANJAY, is batting. GRAHAM (cont'd) Excuse me. There used to be houses here ...

dialogues.speaker: SANJAY
dialogues.text: All knocked down.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: And the people? The families?  62 63 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 36.

dialogues.speaker: SANJAY
dialogues.text: They move. Graham nods, turns to look at the giant structure that ha taken over, then turns back.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Don't grip so tightly with your right hand. Sanjay looks puzzled. GRAHAM (cont'd) On the bat. The right is just a guide. Keep your left elbow high, play down the line of your arm, and then you'll hit through the ball .. Sanjay looks at him, squinting in the sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ajit is wheeling Muriel through the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: When can I go back to England?

dialogues.speaker: AJIT
dialogues.text: As soon as you can walk onto the plane. How does the hip feel?

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: They must have got lucky.

dialogues.speaker: AJIT
dialogues.text: It’s strange. I think the more operations they perform, the luckier they get. He glances down at Muriel, who betrays no sign of getting Ajit’s joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn is still searching for the right address. She's turned off the main road, and is heading down a narrow si streets. The city has become denser, and the walls seem t have closed in. She pushes her way through the crowded market.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncertain, Evelyn turns down a narrow alley, and suddenly finds herself in an enclosed courtyard strewn with makeshift washing lines. The atmosphere is faintly threatening. As she tries to find her way out, she becomes aware that she is being watched: the walls are full of doorways, and people have come out to stare at her. She has stumbled into their home. Evelyn tries to suppress her panic, turning from one face to another.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry. I didn’t realise - She backs into a kind of flatbed trolley, piled high with cooking utensils, which clatter noisily to the ground. Sh goes to pick them up. EVELYN (cont’'d) Oh, I’m dreadfully sorry... A man is staring at her: SURESH.

dialogues.speaker: SURESH
dialogues.text: Yes. EVELYN (cont'd) I’m sorry, I’m just trying to get to this address.

dialogues.speaker: SURESH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Do you understand me? Can you help me find this place?

dialogues.speaker: SURESH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Is that yes you understand, or yes you can help me?

dialogues.speaker: SURESH
dialogues.text: Yes. Some of the children who have gathered laugh at this, and the tension is broken slightly.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Let’s go with both, shall we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 64 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suresh‘s flatbed trike is rolling down the street, piled impossibly high with bundles of brightly-coloured textile On the back, enthroned in the fabric, is Evelyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham is playing cricket with the teenagers. He’s good, too. He whacks a ball off into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (triumphant)

dialogues.speaker: YES
dialogues.text: A boy runs off to fetch the ball. Graham half-runs, half- walks to the other end, then turns for a second run, breathing heavily. Then walks back to the crease, gets ready for the next delivery. It’s hot and he’s tired, but he hasn’t felt this good for years.

dialogues.speaker: SANJAY
dialogues.text: Give me the ball. I can take him. He turns cheerily to Graham. SANJAY (cont'd) Down is where you're going, Uncle.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Come on. Do your worst. They’re both enjoying the banter, as Sanjay heads back to the beginning of his run-up, then turns and sprints in to As Graham watches Sanjay running towards him, Sanjay seem to slow, his movements becoming sluggish, never seeming t reach the crease. He looks at the faces of the other boys frozen, waiting. The ball seems to take forever to leave Sanjay’s hand. Graham steps back, completely fails to play a stroke, and is bowled.

dialogues.speaker: SANJAY
dialogues.text: That's what I’m talking about! I felt the need, the need for - Graham still hasn‘t moved. SANJAY (cont'd) Are you alright, Uncle? Graham finds his voice at last.  65 66 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 39.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suresh brakes, stops outside a glass-clad high-rise building.

dialogues.speaker: SURESH
dialogues.text: Yes. Suresh helps Evelyn down off the back.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: SURESH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: This is it?

dialogues.speaker: SURESH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Then thank you. You’re very kind.

dialogues.speaker: SURESH
dialogues.text: Yes. He rides off. Evelyn looks nervously up at the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brightly-lit open plan office on a high floor of the building. The city sprawls magnificently below. Partitions divide off the cubicles. Within them sit rows of workers, all early 20’s, all with headsets clamped to their ears. As chaotic as the streets of Jaipur are, this place is immaculate, controlled and efficient. We hear snatches of what they’re saying.

dialogues.speaker: TELEMARKETERS
dialogues.text: Thank you for talking to us today «+. We do appreciate your call ++. While I have you on the phone, can I talk to you about our special offers ... your call is important to us ... now is there anything else I can help you with ... shouldn’t take more than five minutes ... your custom is valuable to us ... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 39A. TELEMARKETERS (cont'd) I'm afraid I’1l have to refer that to my supervisor ... just a routine security check before we start ... Thank you for talking to us today .... Through a glass partition, Evelyn can be seen sitting at desk, talking to someone.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAY (late 20’s) is talking to Evelyn.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: You’re sure I can’t offer you something? We have English Breakfast Tea. Building Tea, as you call it.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Builder's tea. It’s called builder’s tea. And no, I’m fine. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: Tell me then. How can I help you? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I don’t think you can. I’m sorry, I shouldn’t have come. She stands.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: Wait -

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I saw your advertisement in the local paper, and it specifically mentioned the ability to talk to older people. But this is not what I imagined ...

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: You came for a job?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I've wasted your time.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: Mrs Greenslade. Everyone working here is a graduate of a good university. This is a place for ambitious people. Young people.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I see that. Good day.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: Please. One second. Evelyn stops. JAY (cont'd) It is really builder's tea?

dialogues.speaker: DAY 67
dialogues.text: 68 69 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 41.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Yes. We dunk biscuits into it.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: You dunk?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: It means lowering a biscuit into your tea, letting it soak in there, then trying to calculate the exact moment just before it dissolves to whip it up to the mouth, and enjoy the blissful union of biscuit and tea combined. (beat) It’s more relaxing than it sounds.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: Perhaps you can help us after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few minutes later. From the open-plan office Evelyn can be seen talking to Jay. One person watching is SUNAINA (20's). She’s talking on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: We do appreciate your custom, which is very important to us. And can I draw your attention to our special - But the person at the other end has hung up. Sunaina starts to dial another number. Then the clock hits 11, and a buzzer sounds. Sunaina gets up, heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dozens of motorcycles are parked in front of the building People are hanging around chatting and smoking. Sonny arrives on his motorcycle, a bag of marigolds strapped to the pillion seat. Sunaina, who is with some friends, spots him, comes over. She smiles as he pulls her to him.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: I get two breaks in eight hours. Explain to me why I would want to waste one of them with you -  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 42. He kisses her. She kisses him back.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Leave this place. Come and work for me.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: You can‘t afford me.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I cannot afford anything.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: Still tempting. I miss you. Am I coming round tonight?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Let’s meet somewhere else. I will rent a hotel room.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: Sonny, you own a hotel. It has many rooms.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Some of them now occupied. With actual real guests.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: Paying guests?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Why must you nitpick? It is not an attractive quality.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: It isn’t? They kiss again, start to make out a bit. Then ..

dialogues.speaker: JAY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sunaina! They turn to see Jay who has come out of the Call Centre. JAY (cont'd) (calling, to Sonny) You can let go of my sister now. Break’s over.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Hello Jay.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: Sonny boy.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Don‘t call me that. Jay smiles, holds the door open for Sunaina.  70 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 43.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: Let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean is sitting in a chair, reading. Graham comes up the path.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Good evening, Your Honour.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Mrs Ainslie. I hope you had a good day. What did you get up to?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Well, I started in my bedroom, where I had a lovely couple of hours giving all the cockroaches names. Then after a lunch that will long have a place in my heartburn, I came out here ... and stared blindly at a book waiting for someone - anyone to rescue me. And how glad I am it was you.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Why would you not go out? There’s so much to see. Jean had hoped for some appreciation of her wit, and is floored by his question. She can hardly understand, let alone tell him, the depths of her discomfort. GRAHAM (cont‘d) Open your eyes, Mrs Ainslie. All life is here, I tell you. Jean stares at him. He goes on through the archway into the hotel. Then stops. GRAHAM (cont'd) I could talk to the chef, if you like. Perhaps get you some grilled chicken, plain rice.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I would appreciate that very much. Graham goes on in. Jean just sits there. Wishing he’d come back out again.  71 72 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel is back. She’s in her chair, on the terrace outsid her room. A young hotel worker, ANOKHI, brings out a tray of food t her. Muriel watches her, but Anokhi is deferential, won't meet Muriel’s eyes. She puts the tray down and leaves. Muriel just sits there, glaring balefully into the night, the untouched tray of food by her side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn comes into the dining area. Graham is there, at a table in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Good evening. Evelyn sits at her table. EVELYN (cont’d) I trust you had a good day?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I‘d rather hear about yours.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I got a job. My first. Ever. I’m going to be a sort of cultural advisor.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: A role I'm sure you’ll perform with great distinction. He’s about to inquire further, when Evelyn sees Douglas a Jean emerge from their room.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Perhaps if you wouldn’t mind keeping that news to yourself.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I’m flattered you shared it with me. He turns to greet the new arrivals. GRAHAM (cont’d) Good evening, the Ainslies.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 45.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Have you had a good day?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Spectacular. (to Graham) I went to the temple you told me about. A place of meditation and peace, quite stunning.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: So spiritual, I bet you hardly noticed the smell of elephant dung.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: No elephants, sadly. Still none. (to Graham) I thought I might see you there. Where did you get to instead?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Yes, where do you get to every day?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Well, I’ve just finished telling Mrs Greenslade all about it. Evelyn registers the lie, but says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I’m sure she wouldn’t mind hearing it again. She waits. But Graham is as elusive as he is tactful.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I talked to the chef for you. He said it will be no problem.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Did you hear that, Douglas? Plain grilled food; manna from heaven.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: I don’t have to have it too, do

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (to Graham) I don’t know how to thank you.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: (to Evelyn) You really should see this temple.  73 74 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 46.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I‘d like that very much.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: But maybe take a clothes peg for your nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham and Evelyn emerge through the arch heading for the rooms. Graham starts down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Goodnight to you. He seems about to say something else. She waits for a moment, then walks on. GRAHAM (cont'd) Mrs Greenslade?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Evelyn.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Can I show you something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later. Evelyn is sitting in front of Graham’'s collage.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I grew up here. Just a short drive away. It was a big house, and we had servants, everyone did. We knew their wives, their children. One boy, Manoj, became my friend. We played a lot of cricket together, played anything we could. And that’s how it stayed for years. Until one night, he became something more. (beat) We had a few months, we had that. There was a weekend in Udaipur, we sat by a lake and watched the sun go down, and I remember thinking ... I will never be this happy again. And I was right. Because quite suddenly it was over. We'd fallen asleep, and they found us. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: 75A
dialogues.text: 76 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 47. GRAHAM (cont'd) (beat) For me it was bad enough. But I already knew who I was, and I think my family had guessed. For Manoj, the disgrace was absolute; a double taboo. His father was fired, they were sent away, all of them. I don’t know what I could’ve done, but it should've been more than nothing. I put up no fight. I let it happen. (beat) Soon afterwards I went to England, to University. I always told myself I’d come back. But I never did.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Until now.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: And now I think .. what if I am the last person on earth he wants to see? Evelyn says nothing. GRAHAM (cont'd) I don’t think I can go through with it.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Do you want to see him again?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. Oh yes.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Then you must.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the bell tolls, the faithful arrive at the temple for morning prayers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn stands outside her room, listening to the bells, sipping a cup of tea, pensive. She looks down into a dilapidated part of the building, where the staff are housed. Women in bright saris go about their business. INT/EXT. MURIEL’S ROOM/VERANDAH, MARIGOLD HOTEL ~ DAY 76 From her wheelchair, Muriel is re-making her bed. She tucks in a perfect hospital corner.  77 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 48. She looks up. Anokhi is on the verandah, replacing her untouched supper tray with breakfast. Anokhi is about to leave, but stops. Then she goes to fetch Muriel’s jar of pickle from the windowsill, and places it on the table. Muriel watches, then wheels herself outside, looks at the tray. From outside, Sonny’s voice can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: And so now that we are fully operational, Mr Maruthi, it is clear that with a small injection of funds for the Phase Two Development ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brimming with confidence, Sonny is walking a wealthy investor, MR MARUTHI, around the grounds. Some builders are dismantling scaffolding.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: «+. the Best Exotic Marigold Hotel can rise like a phoenix to its previous state of glory. And when I say small injection, I mean small in the sense of medium- sized. Possibly larger.

dialogues.speaker: MR MARUTHI
dialogues.text: This hotel was never glorious.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Just the phoenix part then.

dialogues.speaker: MR MARUTHI
dialogues.text: How many rooms will there be?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Many.

dialogues.speaker: MR MARUTHI
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: A great amount. Plenty of rooms, no question. They’ve arrived in the courtyard. SONNY (cont‘d) I am not a details man, Mr Maruthi.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 49,

dialogues.speaker: MR MARUTHI
dialogues.text: Nor was your father. They see Muriel on her verandah.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Mr Maruthi, I present to you one of our beloved guests. Dear Mrs Donnelly, please describe in as much detail as you desire your experience of the ambience and atmosphere of the Best Exotic Marigold Hotel.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Kill me. Kill me now. Sonny steers Mr Maruthi towards the reception, speaks quietly.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: The wheel is spinning. But the hamster is dead. He stops, as he sees an elegant older woman standing in t doorway. This is the redoubtable MRS KAPOOR. SONNY (cont’d) Mummyji! What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: You called. I came.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I couldn’t have called. The phones don’t work.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: That’s why I came. 78 INT. SONNY’S OFFICE. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 78 Moments later. Sonny closes the door behind him. His mother starts going through the contents of his desk.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: Who was that man out there?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: The contents of this desk are mine. Don’t open the drawers. I must insist you don’t open the drawer. Mrs Kapoor opens the drawer.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 50. SONNY (cont’d) Tell me why you have come.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: Do I need a reason to visit my favourite son?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: No. He is in his mansion in Delhi.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: My second favourite.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: He went to Kerala to make his fortune.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: But make it, he did.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: As I will make mine. I have a dream, Mummyji. A most brilliant one: to out-source old age. And not just for the British. There are many other countries where they don’t like old people too.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: Your brothers own a third of the hotel each, they are entitled to a third of the profits.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Success does not happen overnight, Mummyji. This is blue sky thinking, and it requires long-term strategy and patience.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: How is your girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I look forward to you meeting her.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: And I look forward to you meeting the woman you will marry. She is from a good family in Delhi.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I can marry as I choose, Mummyji. I need no permission.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: I presume it is your girlfriend who teaches you such nonsense. One reason not to marry her.  79 80 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 51.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: What if I love her?

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: An even better reason. Now send Young Wasim to the car for my luggage.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: He cannot carry, he has a dicky back ... wait, your luggage? How long are you staying?

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: As long as it takes.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Jean is looking out of her bathroom window, down into the courtyard. She sees Graham come out of his room. She turns back to the mirror, looks at herself. EXT. MURIEL’S TERRACE. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 80 Near to Muriel, Anokhi is sweeping the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: You won't get the dirt out like that. Anokhi just smiles at her radiantly. MURIEL (cont'd) I worked in service for years, looked after a lovely house. I kept it spotless. You need a bit more pressure on that brush. Graham walks past, on his way out.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: She won't speak English. She’s what used to be called an Untouchable. An outcast, born below society. To a good Hindu, even her shadow is polluted. He greets Anokhi in Hindi, and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Where d’you go every day? Is it a woman? Nip round there for a curry and a bit of afters?  81 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 52.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. I’m gay. Although nowadays more in theory than practice. Good day. He leaves. A moment later, Jean comes rushing out. Immediately she realises two things; first, that Graham h already gone. And second, that Muriel is watching her.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Good morning. Muriel says nothing. JEAN (cont'd) Lovely day. Still nothing from Muriel. JEAN (cont'd) Lovely. (beat) Lovely. She turns and goes back in. Muriel thinks for a while, then turns to Anokhi.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Long old life, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A classic colonial building, straight out of the English Raj. Madge is being shown around by an elderly secretary, MR DHARUNA.

dialogues.speaker: MR DHARUNA
dialogues.text: The Viceroy Club was opened by the great Lord Kitchener himself, and many of the fixtures have remained unchanged since then.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Yes, I see that. Perhaps you could tell me a little about the clientele? Any maharajahs? Wealthy widowed land-owners?

dialogues.speaker: MR DHARUNA
dialogues.text: It ig not the policy of this club to divulge details of our members. They go past a very handsome older Indian man. Who radiates wealth and privilege.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 53. MR DHARUNA (cont'd) Good morning, Your Excellency.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Where do I sign up?

dialogues.speaker: MR DHARUNA
dialogues.text: The admission fee is 120,000 rupees, and thereafter 15,000 rupees each month.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: I wonder if I might get a little discount. Owing to my status.

dialogues.speaker: MR DHARUNA
dialogues.text: Your status, madam?

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Yes. One was rather hoping to fly under the radar, but one is a member of the Royal Family.

dialogues.speaker: MR DHARUNA
dialogues.text: Which member, madam?

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: I’m Princess Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: MR DHARUNA
dialogues.text: (bowing slightly) It is most surely an honour to meet you. And may I say how well you look. Especially taking into account that you died nine years ago. (beat) Your real name please, madam. And 120,000 rupees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham comes into the chaotic office. The bookish official, MR CHIDAMBRAM, is behind the desk.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: MR CHIDAMBRAM
dialogues.text: Good morning, Sir. Did I not say that we will contact you when there is information regarding your inquiry?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yes, you did say that. You did.  83 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11

dialogues.speaker: MR CHIDAMBRAM
dialogues.text: While it is most pleasant to see you, your presence does not actually accelerate our investigation.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I‘ll try not to come in tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: MR CHIDAMBRAM
dialogues.text: I expect I will see you then.
83 None of the operators are on the phone. Instead they are sitting in a semi-circle, looking curiously at Evelyn. Wh is sitting next to Jay, a little daunted by the attention

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: +..You ring in the morning. Let’s assume the person answering will be a woman. She will have had her breakfast. Tea or coffee. Semi-skimmed milk, always. If she’s under 50 she’1ll be contemplating yet another diet, over 50 she’ll have more or less given up, and be eating toast. The radio may be playing, or more likely daytime TV. A chat show, or a programme with a moderator speaking to a panel of young women whose boyfriends have all slept with their mothers. The girlfriends’ mothers, I mean, not their own. Although ... Anyway, then the boyfriends usually come out, and everybody fights. Sunaina is in the audience. She calls out.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: I’m not surprised people hang up on us. Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: That’s the point. When the phone rings and it’s this robot ... nobody wants a machine, but it’s almost worse when it’s a person behaving like one. All these sales cliches just strung together. ‘Your call is important to us’. Is it? Well then sound like it.  84 85 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 55.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: ‘Your custom is valuable’.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
