dialogues.text: Right. That one. Don’t ever say that.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: ‘Service is our middle name’.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Yes, when your middle name is actually ...

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: Shantanu.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Which is beautiful. You people are young, vibrant, real. I’m sure the typical housewife would enjoy talking to each and every one of you.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: Her morning sounds like fun. What are you doing here? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I suppose I'm not typical anymore. (to Jay) Is that the sort of thing? INT. MADGE’S ROOM - EVENING 84 Madge is at her mirror, doing her make-up with great care She looks beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madge walks up the gravel path towards the magnificent building. She’s superbly dressed, looks great. She goes up to the BARMAN.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Would there be any wealthy single men in tonight?

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: There is one. Madge puts some money into his breast pocket.  86 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 56.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Perhaps you could seat me next to him?

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: This way, madam. He leads her along across the terrace. Madge follows, checking her hair, her breath, etc. The barman reaches an ornate suite of furniture. There's someone sitting there, his back to us, an elegant arm draped over the side of the chair. BARMAN (cont'd) His Royal Highness Prince Michael of Kent. The man rises from his chair and turns. And Madge is left staring at Norman. There’s a pause. Then Madge reaches into the barman’s breast pocket, and removes her money.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: I‘1l have that back, thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham comes through the courtyard, heads for his room. Muriel is on her verandah.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Good evening. Muriel nods at him, and he goes on into his room. A moment later, Jean sits down next to Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You know where he goes. I know you know. But you won’t tell me. Muriel says nothing. JEAN (cont'd) I can get Hobnobs out here, you know. I know a way. (beat) As many as you want. Milk or plain. Long pause.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Public Records Office.  87 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 57.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge construction, centuries old, with a series of step reaching down deep into the earth, so people can climb do to get their water. Young couples sit on the steps in the evening heat, boys leap into the water. Sonny and Sunaina are watching the swimmers.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: My father used to bring me to this well to swim. He said the water was better, and so were the people we would meet. (beat) He would have liked you so much. Sunaina smiles at this. SONNY (cont‘d) My mother doesn’t want us to be married.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: She hasn’t met me yet.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: She doesn’t need to meet you . Sunaina absorbs this. SONNY (cont‘d) She knows you are not from Delhi. That you have no family money, and work in a call centre. You are a part of a new India she cannot welcome.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: Isn’t this where you tell her what you want?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: That conversation will be easier when the hotel is a success.

dialogues.speaker: SUNANINA
dialogues.text: Do you love me?  88 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 58.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I have found a new investor. I am most optimistic that he will enable us to move forward with Phase Two of the Marigold Hotel Project

dialogues.speaker: SUNANINA
dialogues.text: Shouldn't you finish Phase One first?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: In business, if you stand still, you move backwards. No, I have that wrong. If you stand still, you are overtaken by people going the other way. Wait -

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: You didn’t answer the question. Do you love me?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: My feelings for you cannot be reduced to a single word.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: It’s a nice word, Sonny. And people like hearing it.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Sunaina, please. My mother is wrong. It is you who are too good for me.

dialogues.speaker: SUNANINA
dialogues.text: You say that a lot. You shouldn’t I’1l start to believe you. They watch the boys in the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madge and Norman are sitting together. Norman is looking across at the bar, where an attractive older ex-pat lady sitting, thus far resisting Norman's attempts to catch he eye.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I still think you’re cramping my style.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Please. You have no style to cramp.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 58A.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: That lady at the bar keeps looking at me.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: As one would something in a museum.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Why must you mock? I just want to feel young again, to be needed as much as I need, if only for one night, one wonderful night. Tell me you don’t know how that feels.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 59. Silence for a bit.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Give me a minute. Then join us. She gets up, heads towards the bar. Where she sits a couple of seats away from the woman. Who is called CAROL. She sits there a moment, then sighs, and starts to talk t the barman. MADGE (cont‘d) Rejected again. Many years ago, that man over there gave me the most extraordinary night of my life. He may seem coarse and uncouth, but that only disguises a tenderness and an exquisite sensitivity to a woman's needs Norman arrives at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Those drinks not ready yet? Madge turns to Carol.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: They say patience is passion tamed. Carol smiles. MADGE (cont'd) I’m Madge.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Carol.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: And this ... is Norman.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Carol? As in Christmas? Madge winces.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Great. Silence.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 60.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: So what brings you to Jaipur, Carol?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Yes, Carol. What brings you to Jaipur?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I run a small boutique travel agency. But I’ve actually lived here all my life. My father worked in the Foreign Office. Another silence.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: You're very fit.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Oh god.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I mean you look like you keep yourself in shape. Physically.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Well, I did join a gym last year. It cost a fortune, and I didn’t get any fitter. Apparently you have to actually go. Madge laughs. Norman doesn’t. Then realizes that it was a joke, lets out a too-loud bray of laughter. CAROL (cont‘d) And so what do you do, Norman?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Oh. I'm...

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Norman's in business.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Yes.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 61.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What business?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (to Madge) You tell her.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Import-Export.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Although these days there's rather more Ex- than Im-, if you see what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m afraid I don’t. Madge gets up.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: I have to splash some water on my face. Please God I drown in it. She heads for the bathroom. Norman and Carol share another silence.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Well look, it’s been lovely chatting.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: No it hasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No. It hasn’t. But I really must —

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Carol? She was about to go, stops. NORMAN (cont’d) Can we drop all this pretence? And start again? I’m not charming. I‘m not good at repartee. And I’m not a plutocrat with the sexual capacity of a rutting rhino. My name is Norman. And I'm lonely.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: My name is Carol. So am I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minutes later. Madge comes out of the bathroom.  90 91 92 93 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 62.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Day 22. Like Darwin's finches, we are slowly adapting to our environment. And when one does adapt, my god, the riches that are available. Madge looks across the bar. And is startled to see Norman and Carol chatting up a storm, laughing together. As she watches, Norman orders more drinks, then turns smiling back to his new friend. Madge walks slowly out of the bar, and into the night. INT. EVELYN’S ROOM. MARIGOLD HOTEL - MORNING 90 Evelyn is at her computer, typing.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There is no past that we can bring back by longing for it ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ajit is pushing Muriel down to the gate for her morning constitutional.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: ++. only a present that builds and creates itself as the past withdraws ... INT. SUPERVISOR’S OFFICE. CALL CENTRE - DAY 92 Jay is counting out cash into Evelyn’s hand; her first paycheck.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: And India, like so many things in life, like life itself I suppose, is about what you bring to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ajit is pushing Muriel through a poor neighborhood. Murie is looking left and right, astounded by the life she sees

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Where's this? Where are we?

dialogues.speaker: AJIT
dialogues.text: Janta Colony Kachi Basti.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: What happened to my usual route?  94 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 63.

dialogues.speaker: AJIT
dialogues.text: Anokhi has invited you to her home.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: You didn’t tell me.

dialogues.speaker: AJIT
dialogues.text: You'd have said no. INT. DOUGLAS AND JEAN’S ROOM. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 94 Jean is sitting, reading a book.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Will you check in at the bank? Douglas emerges from the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS,
dialogues.text: I checked yesterday. And the day before. As requested. (beat) Will you be staying in again?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Why do you ask that every morning?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Because I hope for a different answer. Because I think you’1l be hurt if I don’t. And because it's not healthy for you to spend all day and every day in the confines of the hotel. He goes back into the bathroom. Jean changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I didn’t sleep a wink. The tap in there never stops dripping.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I talked to Young Wasim about it.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No idea. It was in Hindi. Douglas comes out of the bathroom, holding the tap. DOUGLAS (cont’d) I thought I might get it fixed myself.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 63A.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You? When?  95 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 64.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: No time like the present. Actually I say that, but I enjoyed yesterday, and I'm optimistic about tomorrow too.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I wish I could say the same. DOUGLAS. So do I. He goes. Jean sits for a while, looking utterly disconsolate and lost. Then she gets up, goes over to the balcony. Down below she can see Graham leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madge is sitting on a chair. Norman arrives.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Your Madgesty.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: I gather the night went well.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Would you like to hear about it?

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Not in the least.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Good. Because you’re going to. Two drinks, some sexually charged banter - Douglas comes out, carrying a tap. And heads out of the archway.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Morning. Lovely day.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Good morning. They watch him leave.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Two drinks, some sexually charged banter, and we were heading back to her place. Bidding the rickshaw farewell, I walked her to the door. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 65. NORMAN (cont'd) And there, my young friend, I leaned forward, and I kissed her. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: And what?

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Is that all? You didn’t seal the deal?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: We have a date next week.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: What is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I wanted to prolong the anticipation. To spend some time with the knowledge that soon I'm going to eat, drink, and laugh with someone, hold her to me, kiss her softly. Then go back to her place and get my end away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The market is buzzing with commerce. Evelyn is at a stall selling fabrics, talking to the vendor, AKRAM.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: (holding up a pashmina) How much for this, please Kitna paise

dialogues.speaker: AKRAM
dialogues.text: One thousand rupees Ek hazaar rupia

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Thank you. She reaches for her wallet. Then Douglas speaks from behind her.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: No no, forgive me. That’s not how it works.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 65A. Evelyn turns, happy to see him.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 66.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: And to you. Sorry to butt in, but you don’t ask him how much he wants, you just tell him how much you'll pay. (to Akram) She’ll give you two hundred. Absolutely no more, final offer.

dialogues.speaker: AKRAM
dialogues.text: One thousand rupees.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Pity. (to Evelyn) Now walk away. Walk away.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: But -

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: I know what I’m doing. Evelyn complies, and they turn and walk away.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Yes. The thing is, you see, I did actually want to buy that. To brighten up my room.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: He’1ll come after us.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Do you think so?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Absolutely. This is how the game is played. Just keep on walking. They push through the crowds. DOUGLAS (cont’d) He’s playing it cool, but he’1l come. They keep walking. DOUGLAS (cont‘d) He's playing it very cool. They keep walking. Then Douglas stops. Evelyn looks at him.  97 98

dialogues.speaker: 98A
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 67. DOUGLAS (cont’d) He’s not coming.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Moments later. They’re back at Akram’s stall. Evelyn counts out the money.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Eight hundred and fifty, nine hundred, nine hundred and fifty, one thousand. She turns to Douglas, smiles. EVELYN (cont'd) You‘ll get him next time. Then she notices something. EVELYN (cont'd) Why are you carrying a tap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean gives up on the sentence she has already read a hundred times, and snaps her book shut. She stands, then sits again. Then stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ajit is now pushing Muriel through a poverty-stricken slu The people live on the streets, or in collapsing tin shacks. Everywhere there is struggle and deprivation. And yet the pervasive atmosphere is nowhere near as depressing as we would expect. The colours are bright, th smiles on the children's faces even brighter. Not that Muriel can recognise the joy, of course. She’s horrified by her surroundings. And acutely aware of the stares of the slum-dwellers. EXT. ANOKHI’S HUT - DAY 98A A primitive brick and cement hut, one of the few amongst dwellings made mostly from sticks and plastic bags. A bunch of young kids are fascinated by Muriel’s wheelchair, pushing it around and taking turns to sit on it.  99 100 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 68. INT. ANOKHI’S HUT - DAY 99 Muriel sits on the only chair. Opposite - squashed together as if posing for a photograp are all the generations of Anokhi’s family: Anokhi hersel her husband, mother, grandmother, and several children. They all smile at Muriel. A long pause. Then Muriel turns to Ajit.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: How soon can I leave?

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. HARDWARE SHOP
dialogues.text: Douglas is talking to JAMSHED, who works behind the counter. Evelyn sits outside.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: You see what I think, and of course I’m no expert, is that the valve seat has eroded, so we’ll need the washer changed and a new seat re-ground. Douglas glances back at Evelyn. Who betrays not the slightest scepticism. Jamshed studies the tap.

dialogues.speaker: JAMSHED
dialogues.text: The gland nut has come away from the spindle.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Well of course, it could be that too. Can you fix it?

dialogues.speaker: JAMSHED
dialogues.text: Not cheaply. Not cheaply. Most expensively indeed. Jamshed takes the tap to a workstation at the back, start to fiddle with it. Douglas joins Evelyn.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: I was in a tuk-tuk the other day, didn’t seem to be taking the usual route back to the hotel. It turned out that the driver had decided to take me to another hotel, that he was sure I would prefer. And of course one wants to believe that he genuinely had my welfare at heart, and that it wasn’t run by. his brother-in-law. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 101 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 69. DOUGLAS (cont'd) One wants to trust, in general, don’t you think? But you never really know, do you? Jamshed stops fiddling with the tap. And takes a hammer t it.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: The day I met my husband was the day the fair came to town. girlfriend and I went on the carousel. Her horse was fine. But when the ride began I felt mine give a little, like it might collapse. Then these strong arms were around me, holding the horse together. And a voice in my ear said “Just trust me”. And I did. Without question. Until the day he died.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: How wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: The sale of our flat went through last week. I had to sell it to pay off Hugh’s debts. (beat) I’ve been forced to get a job out here. Which, in fact, I love. But even at Sonny’s rates, I still couldn’t make ends meet. After what my own husband did to our life savings. (beat) Sono. You're right. You never know. Jamshed holds up the tap. Which is now in several parts.

dialogues.speaker: JAMSHED
dialogues.text: No good. You must be buying another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean walks down the path to the gate. She stops, looks fearfully at the chaotic sea of humanity outside. She's unable to move. Finally, she steps out. And is of course immediately assaulted by the assorted kids, beggars, street vendors, etc. As anxiety begins to engulf her, she quickens her pace, brushing through them as best she can, until she is almos running.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 70. 102 INT. ANOKHI’S HUT - DAY 102 Muriel is still at the tea party. Anokhi speaks. Ajit translates.

dialogues.speaker: AJIT
dialogues.text: She wants to thank you for your kindness.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: I haven‘t been kind.

dialogues.speaker: AJIT
dialogues.text: You‘re the only one that acknowledges her. Anokhi brings out a plate of food.

dialogues.speaker: ANOKHI
dialogues.text: farkha dhal. Chapati.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: I’m not eating that.

dialogues.speaker: AJIT
dialogues.text: You will insult her very deeply if you do not. Muriel looks up. They’re all still watching, waiting, smiling. She looks at Anokhi’s grandmother, as dignified as she is old. Muriel reaches out, takes something off the tray. And has a bite. It’s not too bad.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: I'd still rather a Scotch Egg. Then she sees something through the open doorway: the children have turned her wheelchair on its side and are spinning the wheels. She’s on her feet in a flash. MURIEL (cont'd) Get off! Get off it, you dirty thieving bastards! Several terrified faces turn. One little girl starts to cry. Everyone is staring at Muriel. MURIEL (cont’d) I didn’t see. They were playing. I’m sorry. I’m sorry ...  103 104

dialogues.speaker: 104A
dialogues.text: 105 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean is now in a tuk-tuk, lurching and weaving through th traffic, a handkerchief clasped firmly over her mouth, panic in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JAIPUR
dialogues.text: The corridors are full of people patiently waiting their turn to grapple with a vast bureaucracy. Reaching the top of the staircase, Jean takes it all in. She walks down another corridor. Then stops. Through a doorway, she sees Graham at the desk, talking t Mr Chidambram.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: In the office.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: But I’ve filled out that form. I've given it to you. Many times.

dialogues.speaker: MR CHIDAMBRAM
dialogues.text: There is a process. You are making an enquiry. For each enquiry a form must be filled in.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: But it’s the same enquiry I make every day.

dialogues.speaker: MR CHIDAMBRAM
dialogues.text: And therefore the same form you must fill in. Graham glances towards the doorway, catches sight of Jean Their eyes lock, then Jean pulls back out of sight, panicked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean is hurrying down a corridor. Behind her, Graham emerges from a doorway, and calls to her

dialogues.speaker: GRABAM
dialogues.text: Mrs Ainslie.....?

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 105
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Jean and Graham are sitting in an elegant tea room Jean is still very shaken.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know how you can bear this country. What do you see that I don’t?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Unutterable beauty. Everywhere. In the light, the colours, the smiles, the people who see life as a privilege not a right, and so teach me something every day. The waiter brings their tea.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Is this milk pasteurized?

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Yes madam.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: But that’s not true, is it? You’re just lying to me right now It‘ll be fine. The waiter goes. She looks GRAHAM (cont'd) It’s a pleasant surprise to see you out and about. Is it? at him.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yes. That’s progress. Where were you going?  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 73.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: To the bank. I ... was going to the bank. Not that there’s any reason to think something has changed. But our daughter, you see, she did promise, and one does try to remain optimistic. One has to. Otherwise ... otherwise ... Graham worries she might be about to break down. He reaches across the table, puts his hand on hers. She leans forward, puts her other hand over his, holds on tightly. Graham is startled. He tries gently to pull back, but she holds on.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Jean -

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Oh god. Is it possible you feel the same? She brings his hand to her mouth, kisses it. JEAN (cont'd) The way you talk to me. Your compassion, your understanding ++. the wonderful, tender consideration, it had to be more than just -

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I’m gay. She stares at him. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: As in ... happy? Graham says nothing. Jean lets go of his hand. JEAN (cont’d) Yes. I see. Of course I see. The ghastly inappropriateness of it all settles on them both. JEAN (cont'd) I appear to have humiliated myself. And embarrassed you.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I’m not embarrassed. Jean smiles wanly, grateful for his lie.  107 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Like I said. This country is driving me mad. (beat) Shall we go? EXT/INT. DOUGLAS AND JEAN’S ROOM. MARIGOLD HOTEL 74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn is outside in the courtyard. We don’t see Douglas.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Anything?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Not yet. Evelyn waits a moment.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: How about now?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: One second. Another pause. DOUGLAS (0.S.) (cont’d) Oh good lord.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Listen. The sound of a flowing tap. DOUGLAS (0.S.) (cont‘d) And now ... The tap stops. DOUGLAS (0.S.) (cont’d) No drip. He appears in the doorway, triumphant. DOUGLAS (cont‘d) No drip! He walks towards her, hand in the air. DOUGLAS (cont’d) Hi-five! Evelyn just looks at him. She’s never hi-fived anyone in her life. After a moment Douglas puts his hand down.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 75. DOUGLAS (cont‘d) I’ve never done that before. It just seemed appropriate. Jean has appeared at the other side of the courtyard. Douglas senses her mood, moves towards her. DOUGLAS (cont'd) Darling!

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Mrs Ainslie, how are you? Did you have a good day? Jean doesn’t answer. She’s staring at Douglas. Who looks so happy.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Let me tell you about ours. Your husband of many a year, who has never even known which end of a hammer to use, has actually managed to -

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (suddenly interrupting) We have to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I can’t stay in this country a moment longer.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Why ...?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Do excuse me. She makes a tactful exit. Jean is going past Douglas into their room.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: I don’t understand ...

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Pick a reason. Pick ten. The climate, the squalor, the poverty She goes past him into their room.  108 109 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 76. INT. DOUGLAS AND JEAN‘S ROOM - CONTINUOUS 108

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: «+. we should never have come. This whole trip is a grotesque fantasy. It’s time to go home. Jean starts to pack. Irrationally, compulsively.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Who’s paying for the tickets?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (not hearing him) Look at us. A group of self- deluding old fossils traipsing around as if it’s our bloody gap year. Humiliating ourselves ...

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Not us, we can’t pay. And I don’t see you asking our friends back home ...

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (overlapping) «+. We should just face up to the truth. That we’re all old, we’re all past it. That’s the real truth, the raw, unvarnished fact of the matter. All we're good for now is the beige bloody bungalow with the sodding panic button in the sodding corner ... She stops packing, and subsides onto the bed, crying quietly. Nobody speaks for a while.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: (gently) We just have to make the best of it, darling. I really think that’s the best thing to do.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Yes, well. When I want your opinion, I'1l give it to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An impossibly small roadside clinic. Norman is sitting there, the only man in three rows of brightly dressed women. DR RAMA comes out of the consulting area.  110 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 77.

dialogues.speaker: DR RAMA
dialogues.text: Mr John Smith. No response. The doctor looks at Norman, who has forgotte his own alias. DR RAMA (cont’d) Mr John Smith? Norman jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: That’s right! Me!

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. MARKET/OPERATIONS ROOM. CALL CENTRE
dialogues.text: Sonny is at the flower market, sitting on his motor bike, waiting for the flower vendor to tie up his bundle of marigolds. He‘s on his phone.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Come on. Pick up pick up pick up. The phone is answered at the other end. SONNY (cont’d) (into phone) Sunaina, I must see you. I must. If I cannot hold your body against mine, I swear I will go mad. We cut to the call centre. It’s not Sunaina on the phone, but Jay, who is standing next to her. SONNY’S VOICE (on phone) I yearn for you, I burn for you, Ie

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: I think it’s my sister you're burning for there, Sonny boy.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Jay. Thank you. Jay hands the phone to Sunaina.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Private line, Sunaina. Do those words mean nothing to you?  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 78.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: He took the phone. What could I do?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I miss you. I miss you every moment. Come and see me. Tonight.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: I cannot tonight. It is my parents 25th wedding anniversary. Tell your mother that.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Come after. Come late

dialogues.speaker: SUNANINA
dialogues.text: You’1ll be asleep.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I‘1l be waiting.

dialogues.speaker: SUNANINA
dialogues.text: You’1l be asleep. But i can wake you in that special way....

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: You will sneak in?

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: I’m not ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Neither am I. Absolutely not. There is no shame. You do not have to sneak. (beat) All the same, if you did want to be very quiet, and not let anyone see you, it couldn’t hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman is talking to DR RAMA.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I‘m worried there’s no lead in my pencil.

dialogues.speaker: DR RAMA
dialogues.text: OK. I don’t know what that means.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: No snap in my celery.

dialogues.speaker: DR RAMA
dialogues.text: I’m still not quite with you.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 78A.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I plan to party hearty tonight, but I can’t guarantee that my love gun will fire.

dialogues.speaker: DR RAMA
dialogues.text: Mr Smith -

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Will the lance dance, and the trouser lion roar?

dialogues.speaker: DR RAMA
dialogues.text: What is your problem?  112 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 79.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know if I can still have sex.

dialogues.speaker: DR RAMA
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I’m not a young man anymore, doctor. And I’m a little bit scared. Truth be told, I’m a lot scared.

dialogues.speaker: DR RAMA
dialogues.text: How long since you’ve been with a woman?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: What’s today?

dialogues.speaker: DR RAMA
dialogues.text: Monday.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Six years.

dialogues.speaker: DR RAMA
dialogues.text: I’ve got some pills that’1l help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The back of the hotel, where Sonny envisages his Phase Tw development. Very dilapidated. Anokhi is cleaning pots. Young Wasim sits in the corner. Ajit has just wheeled Muriel into the courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: (to Anokhi) I wanted to tell you something... Anokhi looks up. MURIEL (cont'd) (to Ajit) Tell her. Tell her I was glad to come, glad she invited me. Ajit translates. MURIEL (cont'd) Glad to meet her family. Her grandmother. Her kids. Ajit translates. Anokhi speaks.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 80.

dialogues.speaker: AJIT
dialogues.text: She asks if you have children?

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: I looked after somebody else's. Ajit translates. MURIEL (CONT’D) This one family, years I was with them. I ran the house, looked after the money, did it all, cared for them like they were my own. Ajit starts to translate. But Muriel doesn’t wait. MURIEL (cont'd) That’s the mistake, see. You don't want to get like that, to start feeling part of something. One day they decided I needed some help. I was grateful, I tried to teach her. Not just the books, but how to crisp up the bacon like the gentleman preferred it, the way the little one liked to have her hair brushed. The things you only know if you care. But then they said I was no longer useful to them. Thanked me for my service. As if that’s all it was. (beat) I got a flat in the end. I’m the only one in the building not a foreigner. More Indians there than here! But before I came to this place, my biggest problem was what to do with all the time I had. Because that flat’s so small, I can have the whole place spotless in half an hour. And then what am I supposed to do for the rest of the day? There’s silence for a bit. Then Ajit speaks.

dialogues.speaker: AJIT
dialogues.text: Did you want me translate that as well? Muriel smiles. It’s the first time we’ve seen this. Muriel stops, thrusts something into Ajit’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Give her these.  113 114 115 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 81. Ajit hands Anokhi what Muriel gave him: a packet of Chocolate Hobnobs. This time it’s Muriel who cannot meet Anokhi’s eye. Tries to hide her desire to leave. Ajit turns her chair and pushes her away. Over this, the sound of singing ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman's on his rooftop, under the primitive spout of wat that passes as his shower. Hanging from a nail in the wal the battery radio is pumping out a bizarre Indian cover version of the Chic song “Le Freak”. Norman is naked, and singing along lustily.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Aaaaaah, freak out! Le freak, c’est chic ... Aaaah, freak out! Feet slapping in the soapy water, he performs a nifty dis move. INT. SONNY’S OFFICE. MARIGOLD HOTEL - EVENING 114 Sonny is in his office, going through the accounts. There's a strange ringing somewhere nearby. He pays no attention, then stops and thinks for a moment. Then realises what it is. He sweeps the pile of papers off the desk, starts frantically looking for the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham and Evelyn are having drinks.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I’ve been getting out and about as much as I can, but I feel I’ve hardly scratched the surface. And of course I’d love to see Udaipur. The lake you talked about.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I‘d love to take you. Perhaps - He breaks off. Douglas and Jean have come in. Jean looks rather desperate.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN AND DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: (simultaneously) Good evening.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 81A. An awkward moment. Graham stands.  116 117 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 82.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mrs Ainslie. Please allow me. He pulls a chair out for her. She shoots him a look of passionate gratitude for his exquisite sensitivity.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You’re very kind. But I rather think I’1l turn in early. Goodnight everyone. She goes into her room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel is sitting outside her room, doing the crossword. Madge is coming through the arch, stops dead. Norman is standing in front of her, on his way out. He looks transformed. And rather handsome.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Is this it?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: This is it.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: You’re not worried about the danger of having sex at your age? Norman shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: If she dies, she dies. He leaves. Sonny sprints into the courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Progress, Mrs Donnelly, Mrs Hardcastle! The wheel is turning most assuredly in our favour! He shoots up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas, Graham and Evelyn are looking at the menu. Sonny bursts in.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Mr Dashwood! Everybody! Great news!  118 119 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 83.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: What is it, Sonny?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: They are working, they are working!

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: That is great news. What are working?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: The telephones of the Marigold Hotel.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Well, congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Thank you. I must tell everybody. I must tell my mother! He runs off. Comes back. SONNY (cont'd) Oh wait. You have a phone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham, Evelyn, and Douglas are walking quickly up a quie street.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: It's a false alarm. There’s no way they could find anything in that office. They probably just picked an address at random, just to keep me off their backs. I’m sure that’s what happened. It’s going to be nothing. Don’t you think it’s going to be nothing?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I think you should knock on the door and see.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes I should. (beat) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some men sit under a tree, playing cards.  120 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 84. Across the street, Graham approaches a house. At a polite distance, Evelyn and Douglas wait. Graham knocks at the open door. A woman, GAURIKA, appears. She stares at Graham.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I’m sorry to disturb you so late. My name is Graham Dashwood. A long time ago I -

dialogues.speaker: GAURIKA
dialogues.text: I know who you are. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I am afraid I don’t know you.

dialogues.speaker: GAURIKA
dialogues.text: I am Gaurika. The wife of Manoj.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (after a fraction of a beat) I’m very pleased to meet you. And if you could, if you would tell him that I called around, I‘d appreciate that very much, and - He breaks off. She’s walked past him, looking to the othe side of the road. He turns to look at the men playing cards. Gaurika calls Hindi. A beautiful-looking man looks up. MANOJ. He looks across at the house. Stands up slowly as Graham walks across the street towards him. Graham reaches him. The two men just stand there for a moment. Then they hug very tightly. From the steps of the house, Gaurika watches. Evelyn looks at her, fascinated. Across the street, Manoj and Graham are still holding eac other, unable to let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas and Evelyn are walking.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: (a tiny bit sloshed) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 85. DOUGLAS (cont'd) First time going in to London with my dad, on his commute... He'd always been so extraordinary to me, so unique. But there he was standing on the station platform, utterly indistinguishable from all the other men in suits. And then of course a few years later I was one of them... Hated my job. Hated it. (beat) Sorry, talking too much. Blame a good dinner out.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: What was she thinking?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: His wife. Manoj’s wife. She knew who Graham was. Had he told her? (beat) D‘you think we'll find out tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Not me, I’m heading up to the Badi Mahal Palace. Very excited, been reading all about it.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: I would, if I could remember a word. Evelyn laughs. Then Douglas suddenly grabs her. And pulls her out of the way of a motor bike, zooming past them. Sunaina hasn't realised she nearly hit them, and powers o towards the Marigold. Douglas and Evelyn stand for a moment, startled, holding each other. Something passes between them that embarrasse them both. Then they part quickly, guiltily. They're outside a small restaurant, and with exquisite timing, a group of musicians start to Play a romantic tun

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Come, please. Nice meal, please...  121 122 123 124 125 126 127 128 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 86.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: (namaste gesture) We've eaten, thank you... They continue on their way. Slightly further apart than before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s the middle of the night, and everything's quiet. Or as quiet as it can be in the middle of the usual night-ti Indian cacophony. Sunaina parks her bike outside the hotel, goes on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny is sleeping peacefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunaina moves across the courtyard. Not sneaking, exactly. But making no sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny sleeps on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunaina is definitely sneaking now. She aims down the passage towards Sonny’s room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny stirs, but doesn’t wake up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunaina comes into the bedroom. She takes off her clothes. And climbs, naked, into bed beside the sleeping figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A loud scream. In a different bed, in a different room, Sonny wakes up. And remembers.  129 130 131 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s Sunaina that’s screamed. Because she’s in bed with Madge. Who couldn't be happier.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: A midnight booty call. How utterly marvellous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny hares out of his temporary bedroom, and races down the corridor, towards Madge’s room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunaina has jumped out of the bed and across the room, grabbing one of Madge’s generous scarves to cover her nakedness.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry, I’m so sorry ... I don’t know what your name is, but I’m incredibly sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Don't be. Most action I’ve had in weeks.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: If you could just please not mention - Sonny bursts in.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Do not worry, Mrs Hardcastle! I can explain each and every thing! He sees Sunaina. SONNY (cont’d) Oh my god you are naked. He turns to Madge. SONNY (cont'd) Mrs Hardcastle, I must apologise with deep and profound sincerity -

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: How could you not tell me you weren’t in your room!  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 88.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Yes, Sunaina, to you too I mst apologise with equally deep and profound sincerity. Now go. Get out. Quickly.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: I’m going. Just let me get dressed, and -

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: No no, quicker than that. You must leave, before - Mrs Kapoor flings open the door.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: What is going on here? Who screamed? She sees the nearly-naked Sunaina. MRS KAPOOR (cont'd) No no no no no. No! This is a respectable hotel, not a brothel. (to Sunaina) You, get out. (to Madge) And Mrs Hardcastle, I expected better of you. Actually, this is exactly what I expected of you, but nevertheless -

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: Mrs Kapoor, I’m Sunaina.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: Since I will not be paying for your services, your name is of no interest to me. (beat) How do you know mine? Sunaina is shocked to realise that Mrs Kapoor doesn’t kno her name. Sonny steps forward reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Because this ... is my Sunaina.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: The girl who my son described as not too modern.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: This is getting interesting.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: (to Sunaina) Tell me, please. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: 132A
dialogues.text: 133 134 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 89. MRS KAPOOR (cont'd) Is there anyone in this building you haven’t slept with?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Mummyji, do not get the wrong idea. Sunaina was not here to be with Mrs Hardcastle. She was here to have sex with me! Mrs Kapoor turns to Sunaina. Who is speechless.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: This is the sort of woman you are. OK. Each to her own. But do not ever try and tell me that you are suitable wife for my son. (beat) Find your clothes and go. I don’t expect to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunaina is leaving the hotel, angry and humiliated. Evely and Douglas are coming up the path.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Sunaina? And now Sunaina is even more humiliated. EXT. STREET. MARIGOLD HOTEL — NIGHT 132A Sunaina roars away on her scooter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same street. The sun is just coming up, and traders a setting up their stalls, spreading their wares on rugs on the ground. One trader is unloading some fruit. A few guava roll off the edge of his wagon. Someone picks them up for him. It’s Graham, who smiles as he puts them back. The trader gives him a fresh one. Graham takes it, and walks on, munching the delicious fruit. A contented man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman is sitting on a stone bench under a spreading tree  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 90.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How did it go? Norman turns, to see Graham standing above him.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I have seen the top of the mountain. And it is good. Graham nods, sits down next to him. They gaze out at the waking city. Norman is

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I saw someone yesterday, a man I hadn't seen for many years. A man I’ve loved all my life. a bit startled by this.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: A man.....?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Carry on.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (smiling, unperturbed) I didn’t know how he’d been in the meantime, didn’t want to guess. I brought disgrace upon him and his family, and imagined he might hate me for it. (beat) But we talked all night. He’s been happy. He’s led a peaceful life, married to a woman who understood him and loved him nonetheless. But he’s never forgotten me. That’s what he said. (beat) I asked his forgiveness anyway. He said he had nothing to forgive me for. That instead I should forgive myself. (beat) All that time. All that time I believed I’d sentenced him to a life of shame. When I was the one in prison. (beat) But not any more.  135 136 137 138 139 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 91. Silence for a while.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Top of the mountain.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yes. Norman smiles, then stands and goes on inside. Graham settles back into his chair, looks out at the worl GRAHAM (cont'd) Not any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman comes into the courtyard. Madge, sipping from a cu of chai, calls down from her verandah.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: How was the night?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Rather special. He leaves. Madge just stares after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman on the stairs to his room. He stops, catches his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham is watching a stunningly beautiful bird. A snow crane; white and magnificent. It’s on the grass in front of him. Then it opens its huge wings, takes off. And flies up int the bright blue sky. It’s an extraordinary sight. As Graham watches the snow crane swoop and dip, it appear suddenly to slow and stall, until it seems to hang in the air, almost motionless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman crosses the rooftop to his bedroom. He comes inside, sits on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham is still sitting in the garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 140 141 142 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 92.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You’re back. He doesn’t turn round. Evelyn has come out to the garden. She goes over to him. EVELYN (cont'd) It’s been rather an extraordinary night all round. First tell me your news, and then - She breaks off. Graham is dead.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Day 45. Of course it was inevitable. Put enough old people in the same place, it won't be too long before one of them goes.... Jean, Douglas, Madge, Norman and Muriel shocked and sober

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A train is crossing the endless fields.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn stares out of the window. Madge, Norman, Douglas and Jean are behind her. Opposite sits Manoj. Evelyn turns to look at him, and at Gaurika, Manoj’s wife, who sits beside him.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We all know it'll happen, but few of us know when. Graham died of a heart attack, evidently not his first. So he had a better idea than most what was coming, he just neglected to tell us. His prerogative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three white vehicles are driving across a narrow causeway which barely rises above the surface of the lake. They seem to be floating. Clouds of dust billow behind them.  143 144 145 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 93.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There was talk of sending the body home, but Manoj felt he should have a Hindu burial. At the place they had visited together. Not a holy place. Although for them perhaps it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ruined garden, surrounded by the waters of the lake, crumbling pillared porticoes and arches. What must once have been a royal retreat is now long abandoned and overgrown. Graham's friends stand watching the pyre, transfixed by t flames. Manoj, dressed in white, stands with Gaurika. He recites a Hindi prayer.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: A body takes a long time to be consumed. Many hours for the mourners to remember their dead. The fire must be lit at dawn, and by sunset, there must be nothing left but ash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stripped to the waist, Manoj walks into the water, holdin a bowl.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Where do our souls go? Is that all of us that is left behind? Perhaps the most we can ask is that when we do shuffle off, we do so knowing that we were loved Manoj pours Graham onto the water. The ashes shimmer and dance, caught in the gentle currents. EXT. SERVANT’S GARDEN. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 145 Muriel and Anokhi are in the servants’ garden. Young Wasi sits silently in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: So there’s a process, they call it pickling. I have no idea what it is, or how they do it, but whoever invented it was a smart Man. But the real genius was the one who introduced an onion into the system. That I could never have thought of.  146 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 94. Ajit looks at her, ready to translate. MURIEL (cont’d) No, forget it. Muriel is looking out at the yard. She sees Mrs Kapoor, talking to some surveyors. They’re mapping out the building. Mrs Kapoor sees Muriel watching her, comes over to them.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: Mrs Donnelly, what are you doing here? You should not be here, talking with this one.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: I'm helping her clean. If these pots get any dirtier, you’ll have to serve the food with penicillin.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: We have other rooms. Go to one of them instead. While this is still a hotel. She turns back to the surveyors.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: (to Ajit) What‘s her problem? What’s happening here? Ajit can’t answer. But he knows a man who can. He points to Young Wasim.

dialogues.speaker: AJIT
dialogues.text: He can tell you.

dialogues.speaker: EVENING
dialogues.text: A stunning view over the city. Madge is having a drink with Norman. Douglas is sitting on the wall, but keeps looking down towards the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: When someone dies, you think about your own life. And in my case, there is less of it in front of me than behind. And I don’t want to grow older. I don’t want to be condescended to, ignored and marginalised by society. To become peripheral to the action. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 147 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 95. MADGE (cont'd) I don’t want to be the first person let off the plane in a hostage crisis. They laugh together. And don’t even see Douglas go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The landing is large, and open to the sky. Evelyn has jus come up the stairs to go to her room. She’s leaning again the stone baluster.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS,
dialogues.text: I wondered where you’d been. Evelyn turns. Douglas is on the stairs above her. DOUGLAS (cont’d) We‘re all up top, having a drink.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I went to see Gaurika. Manoj’s wife. I wanted to ask her what she knew. And the answer was that she knew everything, that he’d loved another man, and always would. He told her when the marriage was arranged. (beat) They had no secrets from each other, none. Suddenly she's crying. Unable to stop. Douglas puts his arms around her, and holds her to him. EVELYN (cont‘d) And that’s right, don’t you see? That must be right. Because what is the point of a marriage in which nothing is shared? Her words hang in the air. They stand there for a moment. Jean has come out of her room, and stands there, watching them.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Mrs Greenslade, might I have my husband back now? They spring apart. JEAN (cont’d) Douglas? She walks off back into the room. Douglas turns to Evelyn  148 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 96.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Forgive me ...

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Forgive me. Evelyn goes quickly to her room, leaving him standing there. INT. DOUGLAS AND JEAN’S ROOM - EVENING 148 Douglas closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: She was upset.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Spare me your explanations. D’you think I’m jealous?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: I don’t see why else you would have embarrassed me. And Evelyn.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You were already doing a perfectly good job of embarrassing yourself. Can you imagine how ghastly it’s been for everyone to watch you mooning around after that simpering doe- eyed ex-housewife, taking advantage of her loneliness and -

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: God, can you hear yourself? Can you? Do you have any idea what a terrible person you’ve become? Jean is stunned into silence. DOUGLAS (cont’d) All you give out is this endless negativity, a refusal to see any kind of light and joy even when it’s right in your face, and a desperate need to squash any sign of happiness in me or anyone else ... it's a wonder I don’t fling myself at the first kind word or gesture that comes my way. But I don’t. Out of some dried-out notion of loyalty and respect, neither of which I ever bloody get in return.  149 150 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 97. There's a long silence.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I checked my emails. This came. She hands him a piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn comes onto the terrace, and heads for Madge and Norman. She picks up Madge‘s glass.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I just need some water. She drains the glass.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: That was a gin and tonic.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Yes. I know that now.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: What’s happened?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Good evening, the Ainslies. Douglas and Jean are approaching them.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: How are you both?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: We’re particularly well. Douglas, tell them our news. She looks to him, waits. He says nothing. So she turns, and smiles. JEAN (cont'd) We're going home. EXT. EVELYN’S VERANDAH/KITCHEN. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 150 Sonny is with his investor, Mr Maruthi. They emerge from the upper courtyard onto the terrace overlooking the back of the hotel.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 98.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: And so I would ask you to loosen the strings on your purse, Mr Maruthi, and to do it most rapidly. So that Phase Two Development of the Best Exotic Marigold Hotel can begin with immediate effect. Mr Maruthi looks down, sees Muriel. She’s with Anokhi, Ajit, and Young Wasim. He calls down to her.

dialogues.speaker: MR MARUTHI
dialogues.text: Mrs Donnelly, I believe. Sonny spots the danger, tries to lead Mr Maruthi away.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: And now if you would please be following me to the ground floor rooms ... Mr Maruthi ignores him, calls down again.

dialogues.speaker: MR MARUTHI
dialogues.text: How are things at the hotel?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Mr Maruthi -

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: (calling back) Better. They’re going better. Sonny takes a moment to recover.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: You see? Profound satisfaction. Such is the inevitable result of a prolonged stay at the Marigold Hotel. And now Mr Maruthi has spotted something else. The surveyors, who are still taking their measurements.

dialogues.speaker: MR MARUTHI
dialogues.text: What are those men doing?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (Glancing back for a moment) Working for me, Mr Maruthi. To create a home for the elderly so wonderful that they will simply refuse to die! Stare death in the face and say- (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 98A. SONNY (cont'd) (follows Mr Maruthi’s gaze) What are those men doing?  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 99. 151 EXT. KITCHEN/SERVANT’S GARDEN. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 1 Moments later. Through the window, Muriel watches Sonny confronting his mother.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Mummyji, what is going on here?

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: I have spoken to your brothers. They want to sell the hotel. These men are here to value the building.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: They are valuing the land. My brothers do not care about the building. They will knock it down.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: They could just wait a month for it to fall down of its own accord.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: You joke, Mummyji, but inside I know you are not laughing. You do not want to see this dream destroyed. Send these people away.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: No, my son. It is too late. 152 INT. SONNY’S OFFICE - NIGHT 152 Mrs Kapoor is at the desk, going through the accounts. Sonny stands opposite her.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Mummyji, please -

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: These figures do not support your argument.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: There is still time to turn things around. With a small injection of funds, we can -

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: Who is trusting you with that money? Eh? You, who cannot run a chai stand. Just like your father.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 100. Beat. Then Sonny speaks quietly.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Do I remind you of him so much? Is that why you must be cruel to me?

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: You think I am cruel?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: You loved my father. And he loved this hotel.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: (fiercely) Two mistakes. There will not be a third. (beat) Say goodbye to all this, Sonny. And come with me to Delhi. Your life will become easier.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Not easier, Mummyji. Smaller. He leaves. Mrs Kapoor comes back to the desk, fiddling with some paperwork, discomfited. She turns to the doorway. Muriel is there, in her chair.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: Mrs Donnelly. Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Depends. Do you know how to use a computer?

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: I assume you are joking.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Mrs Ainslie said she had an address where I could get some things I need. Some biscuits. She said I could get them on the line.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: I wish you luck. Mrs Kapoor smiles, and leaves. Muriel watches her go, then turns to the computer. Her fingers fly across the keyboard.  153 154 155

dialogues.speaker: 155A
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 101.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train rattles its way through the night. Jean is chatting away, in a better mood than we’ve seen her for some time. Evelyn listens in silence.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: The whole thing is actually tremendously exciting. Not just getting on a plane, but getting on a plane and turning left.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Turning left?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: First class. And home in time for our 40th wedding anniversary. We haven’t yet decided how to mark the occasion.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Perhaps a minute’s silence? INT. SONNY’S OFFICE, MARIGOLD HOTEL - NIGHT 154 Ajit keeps watch, while Muriel is at the printer. Waiting as it disgorges pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tuk-tuks are lined up.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: (hailing a tuk-tuk) Two should fit us all, I think.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I’m actually going to walk. Apparently they're getting ready for a festival.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Perhaps you’d like one of us to accompany you.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: I’m happy to walk with you.  156 157 158 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 102.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I'll be fine. Evelyn speaks to both Douglas and Jean. EVELYN (cont'd) I’m delighted for your daughter‘s success. I wish you all every happiness.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Thank you. Evelyn turns, and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas and Jean are in the tuk-tuk with Madge and Norman There is a sombre atmosphere. A motor-bike hurtles past them, going the other way.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Was that Sonny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A phone is ringing. Christopher is still in bed, his wife Polly asleep next to him. He answers.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Yes ... (can’t believe his ears) Ma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn stands under the awning of the ticket office.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I just wanted to hear your voice. (beat) No, I’m sorry, I didn’t think about the time ... How are you? And Polly? The boys ... how are the boys? She listens to him. She’s holding back tears. EVELYN (cont’d) Oh good, I’m glad you’ve been reading it. Yes. Yes, I’ve made some very good friends. (beat) No, I’m fine, of course I am.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 103. As much as she had wanted to speak to him, she now wants the conversation to be over. EVELYN (cont’d) I think my money is running out, I'd better go. Goodbye for now, darling. I’11 call again later. She hangs up. And stays there with her hand on the phone. Out on the street, Sonny is pulling up. She looks over to him.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Mrs Greenslade. Where are the others?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: They’re on their way to the hotel. Sonny looks around, at a loss. EVELYN (cont'd) What’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I wanted to warn you before you see for yourself of the most Momentous changes that are occurring, absolutely all of them without question for the very positive.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I am delighted to announce the closing of the Best Exotic Marigold Hotel, and the joyful return of all of its inhabitants to their home country.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman and Madge have arrived back at the hotel. Mrs Kapoor is breaking the news to them.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: Please relax in the knowledge that your journey home is being arranged, and paid for by the hotel.  160 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 104.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Our journey here was arranged and paid for by the hotel, and look how that went. I'd rather walk back to England.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I'd rather not go back at all. A voice comes behind them. Carol has come out of the courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Why would you have to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny and Evelyn are still talking.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: And for myself the news is even better. I shall be moving to Delhi to live with my mother, and furthermore I shall be wed to a most suitable person of her choice, whom I look forward very much to meeting before I spend the rest of my life with her.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: But what about your girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: She is no longer my girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: This is a disaster.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Then we must treat it just the same as we would treat a triumph, ig that not what your Mr Kipling tells us? Although of course, here we have a problem. Because I, Sunil Indrajit Kapoor, have never had a triumph, so of course I do not know how to treat one. No, all I have had is an constant series of disasters interspersed with the occasional catastrophe, an unending stream of total -

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Sonny, do you love her? Sunaina?  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 105.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Most deeply.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Have you told her you love her?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: It is because I love her that I must not tell her. She can do so much better than me.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: And you have told her that?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Many times.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Good. Women love it when you say that kind of thing. It’s a powerful aphrodisiac.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: No, of course not. Go and find her right now, before you lose her forever. Her future is hers to choose, and so is yours. You can have anything you want, Sonny. You just need to stop waiting for someone to tell you you deserve it. Or you can just keep failing yourself, and hurting the ones you love -

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Mrs Greenslade, stop drilling! You have struck oil! He goes to his bike, climbs on, and rockets off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madge is sitting, pensive. Carol comes in.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Where’s Norman?  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 106.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Packing.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: But we don’t have to leave yet.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I asked him to come and stay with me.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Is that wise? I’m not sure he’s trained.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You think it’s too soon.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter what I think.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It is too soon. But at our age we can't afford the luxury of taking it slow. And it’s either this or he goes home ... and I don’t want him to go home. Madge looks at her for a while. Then smiles. Beat

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: I wish you both the very best.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You haven’t met anyone?

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: Single by choice. Just not my choice. (beat) I actually think it might be over. For me. With men. And if that’s gone, I’m not quite sure what’s left.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Did you know Norman brought pills? The first night he stayed with me?

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: They obviously did the trick.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I saw them in his pocket. I didn’t want it to be like that. So when I had the chance I swapped them. (beat) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 106A. CAROL (cont'd) He went all night on two aspirin. (beat) It’s never over. Norman appears with his one bag and his battery radio.

dialogues.speaker: 166A
dialogues.text: 167 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 107.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny roars through the streets on his bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn approaches. She sees a taxi waiting outside the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The houseboy is carrying Douglas and Jean’s bags down to the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn comes into the courtyard. Muriel is sitting there. The two women stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Do you want him to see you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny is waiting at a junction, texting into his mobile phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas is checking they haven’t left anything. Jean is a the door. She’s impatient.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Douglas ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunaina picks up her mobile, looks at the message.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. TAXI/STREET. MARIGOLD HOTEL
dialogues.text: Jean is sitting in the taxi, which is driven by BARUM. Douglas climbs in. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: My wallet, I forgot my wallet. One second. Before Jean has a chance to say anything, he goes back in  168 169 170 171 172

dialogues.speaker: 172A
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 108. She watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas comes back into the courtyard, heads towards the staircase to Evelyn’s room. Then Muriel speaks from her verandah.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: She’s not back yet. Douglas stops. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Right. (beat) Then perhaps you could tell her I said goodbye. He turns and walks out. INT. EVELYN’S ROOM, MARIGOLD HOTEL - CONTINUOUS 169 Evelyn is at her window, listening. She turns to watch hi leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Douglas gets back into the taxi.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: (slamming the door) False alarm. Had it the whole time. Let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny roars into the forecourt, gets off his bike, and ru into the building. A SECURITY GUARD goes to stop him, but Sonny's already running up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny keeps going up, floor after floor.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 109.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (yelling) Sunaina! Sunaina! He reaches the seventh floor. Jay appears on the landing above him.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: What's going on? Sonny is doubled over, totally out of breath. Holds up a finger. JAY (CONT’D) Sonny?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I need to see Sunaina!

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: Her shift’s not over. And when it is, she doesn’t want to see you. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Jay, you are the son my mother wished I was; an intelligent man, with a strong head for business. You see things as they are, not as you wish them to be. So fuck off out of my way. Jay doesn’t move. SONNY (cont’d) Or you can give her a message. Sunaina is standing against the wall, unseen by Sonny, listening. SONNY (cont’d) Tell her from me what I should have told her the day we met. What I will announce to anyone who asks. And many who do not. Sunaina speaks to Jay.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: Including your mother?

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: (to Sonny) Including my mother?

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: His mother.  173 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 110.

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: (to Sonny) Your mother.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I will tell every mother in the land.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: (to Jay) What will you tell them?

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: (to Sonny) What will you tell them?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: The only thing that matters in this world. That I love you. And always will. (beat) And by you, I mean Sunaina, Jay, not you. Although if you are to be my brother-in-law, I hope we can become better friends.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: Why is he only saying this now?

dialogues.speaker: JAY
dialogues.text: (to Sunaina) You ask him.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: Why are you only saying this now?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Because, Sunaina, love of my life, no more will I believe that I am not worthy, for only by loving you as you deserve will I become so. On Sunaina’s face as she hears this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cacophonous sound of drumming: a small band of player are beating out a deafening, syncopated rhythm as the Ganeshi festival begins to unfold. Sonny is on his bike, Sunaina riding side-saddle on the back. They’re speeding through the city. Sonny rockets through an arch way up a side street, is confronted by a huge traffic jam. The Ganeshi procession bringing everything to a standstill. He does a U-turn, speeds off back the way they came.  174

dialogues.speaker: 174A
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 lll.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. TAXI/STREET
dialogues.text: Douglas and Jean are sitting in the traffic jam.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: It’s funny. They call it rush hour, but nothing actually moves. (beat) It’s not that funny. (beat) Although I suppose it’s all about context, isn’t it? I mean -

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Douglas?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: If you say one more word, I’1l kill you with my thumbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muriel sits alone in the courtyard, under her awning. Then Carol and Norman appear from reception, followed by Mrs Kapoor. They cross towards the arch.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Where d’you think you’re going?

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: You may well ask. Madge is sitting under the shade of a tree..

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: We’re moving in together.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Already?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: That point has been made.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: The hotel is closing.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Doesn’t have to. Silence. Everyone stares at Muriel. She takes out the spreadsheets.  1748 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 MURIEL (cont'd) I’ve been going over the accounts.

dialogues.speaker: 174B
dialogues.text: If anything, the traffic is now worse. Jean and Douglas's taxi has progressed a few yards, and is now wedged into t arch. The Ganeshi procession is completely blocking the f entrance to the archway. Jean gets out, looks at the sea of unmoving traffic ahead and behind.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous. It could go on for hours. There’s no way we're ever going to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Maybe there is. A rickshaw arrives next to them, swerving through the traffic. It is ridden by IFTI.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You. Can you get us to the airport?

dialogues.speaker: IFTI
dialogues.text: Sorry long way sore legs not possible.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I'll give you everything I have.

dialogues.speaker: IFTI
dialogues.text: Step right in mind your head let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Come on, Douglas. Come on! Douglas gets the suitcases out of the trunk of the cab.

dialogues.speaker: IFTI
dialogues.text: Sorry no manage people and cases.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (grabbing her suitcases) What?

dialogues.speaker: IFTI
dialogues.text: Not possible. Two person, no cases; one person, and cases.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 113.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (taking off her watch) How about if I give you something else? My watch?

dialogues.speaker: IFTI
dialogues.text: (takes it) Sure. Thank you. Still not possible.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: We'll get another flight. We can go back to the hotel, and leave in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Jean, you heard what he said. He can't do it.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: He can do one person, and cases.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Yes, but ...

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Could fate find a better way to tell us what we need to hear?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
