dialogues.text: Which is what?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: That it’s over. It was over a long long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: This is not the time to talk about this. Let’s wait till we get-

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I have to go, Douglas. DOUGLAS. I won't let you.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: No, you'll want to come after me. Chase me to the airport and tell me everything will be fine. But please don't. Because the truth is we both deserve more than we've had. You’re just too kind and too loyal to admit it.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 113A. Beat. JEAN (CONT’D) I will be alright. (she smiles) I’m turning left. She climbs onto the rickshaw.  174¢ 175 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 114. As the drumming intensifies, Douglas stands holding his suitcase, watching her weave through the traffic and out sight. EXT. STREET. MARIGOLD HOTEL - DAY 174¢ Sonny and Sunaina roar towards the hotel, drive into the gate and up the path...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Kapoor is studying the spreadsheets.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: I don't know what any of these figures mean. Sonny and Sunaina drive into the courtyard, screech to a halt. They dismount.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Mummyji? Mummyji!

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: Right here, you do not need to shout.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Do you remember what my father used to say? That nothing happens unless first we dream. Like him I have dreamt, Mummyji, and like him, I have failed. The Marigold Hotel is crumbling into dust. And it turns out I can live with that. But the one thing I will not do is live without this girl. To whom I did not introduce you properly before. (beat) This is Sunaina Shantanu Palawat. The woman I love, and wish to marry.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: I am very pleased to meet you, Mrs Kapoor.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 115. Sunaina puts out her hand. Mrs Kapoor will not take it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) No. I forbid it. I forbid this match. Utterly and completely. Do you hear me, Sonny? This cannot happen. And then a low, rumbling sound comes from the corner. Lik a quiet volcano. Young Wasim is speaking. It’s a long, poetic and heartfel speech. Unfortunately it’s in Hindi.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: What is he saying?

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: What he said to me, I imagine. She turns to Sunaina. MURIEL (con’td) Can you help?

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: He is saying ... he is saying that he has been with this family as long as he can remember. Given them a lifetime of service. And that he remembers another fight, between two young people and their parents. And he remembers the moment where the young man stood up to his mother

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: «+. and said yes, I want to marry this woman. Yes, she is from a different community. But she is smart, she is beautiful, and I love her. Long pause. MRS KAPOOR (cont’d) I don’t know who he’s talking about. She offers Sunaina her hand. MRS KAPOOR (cont’d) Take care of my favourite son. Sunaina shakes her hand.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 116.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: So I’m not clear now. Am I staying or going?

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Depends how you read the accounts.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: The accounts?

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Turns out the original plan is good, it works. Just not in the hands of an imbecile.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I knew that plan was good!

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: What the place needs is more money.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Unfortunately my investor, Mr Maruthi has decided that while he greatly admires my endeavors, he cannot -

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: He's reconsidered.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: You spoke to him?

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: So long as there is someone to help the manager.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: The manager needs no help.

dialogues.speaker: SUNAINA
dialogues.text: Sonny...

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: The manager needs a little help.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: (to Norman) So will you stay? Norman looks at Carol.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I'd like to.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 117.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: In the shack on the roof?

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I sleep in the trees.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (to Carol) We have a double room. Bathroom ensuite. And a fully working door. He points to Graham’s room. SONNY (CONT’D) A guest has recently checked out. Madge can’t believe he just said that.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I'll think about it.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: (to Madge) Mrs Hardcastle ? You’re staying.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: On my own?

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: You're off your game. Lost your confidence, maybe. But you're a thoroughbred. You’1l be back. Madge smiles. MURIEL (con’td) And what about you, Mrs Greenslade? Evelyn has come down, unnoticed by all. Except Muriel.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: What about me, Mrs Donnelly?

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: We haven't talked much, you and I.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: My loss, evidently. (beat) I’m not sure what I should do. Nothing here has quite worked out as I hoped.  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 117A.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Most things don’t. But sometimes what happens instead is the good stuff. (beat) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: 175B
dialogues.text: 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 118. MURIEL (cont'd) Haven’t you got work in the morning? Evelyn nods. MURIEL (cont'd) Besides, he’1ll be back.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: You don’t know him. He’s the most loyal man I’ve ever met.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: 50,000 rupees says I’m right. At your current salary that should take you three months to pay off. Muriel stands up. Everybody stares. She starts to walk slowly but proudly across the courtyard. She reaches the doorway, turns back.

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: If you'll excuse me, someone's waiting to help me make mango chutney. Why did no one tell me about that stuff?

dialogues.speaker: MRS KAPOOR
dialogues.text: Who is the new assistant manager?

dialogues.speaker: MURIEL
dialogues.text: Why? Are you thinking of applying for the job? She gestures for her wheelchair. Sonny rushes up with it. She sinks down. MURIEL (cont’d) ) That’s enough exercise for one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean sits in the rickshaw, surrounded by her luggage, carried by Ifti’s strong legs towards her future.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Day 51. The only real failure is the failure to try. INT. EVELYN’S ROOM, MARIGOLD HOTEL - EVENING 175B Evelyn is at her computer typing.  175¢ 176 177 178 179 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 119.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: And the measure of success is how we cope with disappointment. As we always must. EXT. STREET, CENTRAL JAIPUR - NIGHT 175¢ Douglas, still holding his suitcase, is surrounded by Ganeshi drummers, silhouetted against the lights of the city. The sound fades as he disappears into the celebration, an is replaced by the gentle sound of temple bells, ringing for morning prayers.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We came here, and we tried. All of us, in our different ways. INT. EVELYN’S ROOM, MARIGOLD HOTEL - MORNING 176 Evelyn is still sitting, fully dressed in her room. She’s been up all night. Her alarm clock buzzes. She turns it off. EXT. EVELYN’S TERRACE, MARIGOLD HOTEL - MORNING 177 Evelyn comes out of her room, walks across the terrace.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Some achieved more than others. but we did our best. Nothing else matters. Evelyn walks through the courtyard, and on out of the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn walks down the path towards the street. Then Douglas comes through the gate, with his suitcase. They stand there, looking at each other for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Good morning.  Beat. 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 120.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: It is, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: You’re still here.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: I missed the plane.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: What about Jean?

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: She didn't. DOUGLAS (cont'd) (putting down his suitcase) I had quite an interesting night, actually. I met the same taxi driver, but this time I let him take me to his brother's hotel. Which turned out to be less of a hotel, and more of a brothel, really. They gave me this pipe, said it was apple tobacco, but that’s not what we called it when I was a student. So I made my excuses and left, wanted some time to think. This city at night is extraordinary. (beat) Of course the apple tobacco helped. (beat) Guess what? I finally saw an elephant. Silence for a bit.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I’m late for work. She goes past him.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: She stops, turns. DOUGLAS (cont'd) What time do you finish?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: I get back about 5.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Tea time.  180

dialogues.speaker: 180A
dialogues.text: 181 182 2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 121.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: How do you take it?

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: With a little milk. She turns and walks away. She’s smiling.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Perhaps it's true: we don’t stop Playing because we grow old, we grow old because we stop playing. Douglas is haggling with a motorbike mechanic. He seems t be having more success with the price than in earlier day

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol is lying on Norman’s bed, reading a book, while he washes his socks in a bucket.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: All we really know about the future is that it will be different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madge is chatting vivaciously to someone. It’s the elegan older man we saw earlier. And he seems utterly smitten. EVELYN (V.O.) (CONT’D) So we must celebrate the changes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny and Sunaina race through the streets on his motorbike. Sonny raises a fist in salute.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Let them come. Bring them on. Because as someone once said, everything will be alright in the end ...  2nd Green Revisions 10/01/11 122. Coming from the other direction, another motorbike, Dougl at the handlebars, returning Sonny’s greeting. And on the pillion seat, riding side-saddle, her scarf flying in the breeze, is Evelyn, on her way home from wor EVELYN (V.0.) (cont'd) So if it's really not alright, then trust me: it’s not yet the end.
